Since ancient times, emperors and kings who received the mandateâ€”how have they ever not performed the feng and shan sacrifices? There have been those who performed the rituals without the proper omens, but there have never been those who saw auspicious signs appear yet did not proceed to Mount Tai. Though they received the mandate, their merit did not reach the required level; though they reached Liang Fu, their virtue was not pervasive; though pervasive, they did not have sufficient leisure time; therefore they performed the rituals rarely. The tradition says: 'If for three years rites are not performed, the rites will certainly be wasted; if for three years music is not made, the music will certainly be ruined.' In each generation's time of prosperity, then the feng and shan respond accordingly; when decline comes, they cease. The distant ones were over a thousand years ago, the nearer ones several hundred years ago; therefore their rituals are completely lost and buried, their details cannot be obtained and recorded as heard.

The Shang Shu says: Shun was at the xuan ji jade balance, using it to regulate the seven governments. Then he assembled offerings to the Supreme Deity, offered sacrifices to the six ancestors, gazed upon the mountains and rivers, and universally honored the group of spirits. He collected the five auspicious items, selected auspicious months and days, saw the four peaks' various shepherds, and returned the auspicious items. In the year's second month, he inspected the eastern regions, arriving at Dai Zong. Dai Zong is Mount Tai. He performed the chai sacrifice, gazing and ranking the mountains and rivers. Then he held audience with the eastern queen. The eastern queen refers to the feudal lords. He united the seasonal months and correct days, unified the pitch, measures, capacity, and balance; cultivated the five rites: five jades, three silks, two living, one dead as offerings. In the fifth month, he inspected the southern regions, arriving at the southern peak. The southern peak is Heng Mountain. In the eighth month, he inspected the western regions, arriving at the western peak. The western peak is Hua Mountain. In the eleventh month, he inspected the northern regions, arriving at the northern peak. The northern peak is Heng Mountain. All were like Dai Zong's rites. The central peak is Song Mountain. Once every five years he made an inspection tour.

Yu followed this practice. After fourteen generations, to Emperor Kong Jia: licentious virtue, fond of spirits; the spirits were profaned, two dragons left him. After three more generations, Tang attacked Jie; he wished to move the Xia altar but could not, so he made a Xia altar. After eight generations, to Emperor Tai Wu: there was mulberry millet growing in the court; in one evening it greatly embraced, causing fear. Yi Zhi said: 'Monsters cannot overcome virtue.' Tai Wu cultivated virtue, and the mulberry millet died. Yi Zhi assisted Wu Xian; Wu Xian's flourishing began from this time. After fourteen generations, Emperor Wu Ding obtained Fu Yue as his minister; Yin revived thereby, and he was called Gao Zong. A pheasant climbed the cauldron's ear and crowed; Wu Ding was afraid. Zu Ji said: 'Cultivate virtue.' Wu Ding followed this advice, and his position achieved eternal peace. After five generations, Emperor Wu Yi disrespected the spirits and was killed by thunder. After three generations, Emperor Zhou was licentious and chaotic; Wu Wang attacked him. From this observation, at the beginning they were never not solemn and respectful; later they became somewhat indolent and disrespectful.

å‘¨å®˜æ›°ï¼Œå†¬æ—¥è‡³ï¼Œç¥€å¤©æ–¼å—éƒŠï¼Œè¿é•·æ—¥ä¹‹è‡³ï¼› å¤æ—¥è‡³ï¼Œç¥­åœ°ç¥—ã€‚ çš†ç”¨æ¨‚èˆï¼Œè€Œç¥ä¹ƒå¯å¾—è€Œç¦®ä¹Ÿã€‚ å¤©å­ç¥­å¤©ä¸‹åå±±å¤§å·ï¼Œäº”å¶½è¦–ä¸‰å…¬ï¼Œå››ç€†è¦–è«¸ä¾¯ï¼Œè«¸ä¾¯ç¥­å…¶ç–†å…§åå±±å¤§å·ã€‚ å››ç€†è€…ï¼Œæ±Ÿã€æ²³ã€æ·®ã€æ¿Ÿä¹Ÿã€‚ å¤©å­æ›°æ˜å ‚ã€è¾Ÿé›ï¼Œè«¸ä¾¯æ›°æ³®å®®ã€‚
The Zhou officials say: when the winter solstice arrives, sacrifice to heaven in the southern suburbs, welcoming the arrival of longer days; when the summer solstice arrives, sacrifice to the earth deities. All used music and dance, and only then can the spirits be obtained and properly ritualized. The Son of Heaven sacrifices to all under heaven's famous mountains and great rivers; the five peaks are regarded as the three dukes, the four waterways as the feudal lords; feudal lords sacrifice to the famous mountains and great rivers within their borders. The four waterways are the Jiang, He, Huai, and Ji. The Son of Heaven calls it the Bright Hall and Bi Yong; feudal lords call it the Pan Palace.

After Duke Zhou assisted Cheng Wang, he performed suburban sacrifices to Hou Ji to match heaven, and ancestral sacrifices to Wen Wang in the bright hall to match the Supreme Deity. Since Yu rose and cultivated the altar sacrifices, and Hou Ji did farming and harvesting, therefore there was the Ji temple; the suburban and altar sacrifices have come from this, how revered indeed.

After Zhou conquered Yin, fourteen generations later, the generations increasingly declined; rites and music were wasted, feudal lords conducted themselves unrestrainedly; You Wang was defeated by the Dog Rong, and Zhou moved east to Luo settlement. Qin Xiang Gong attacked the Rong to save Zhou, and began being ranked among the feudal lords. Qin Xiang Gong, having become a feudal lord, dwelt in the western extremity; he considered himself to govern Shao Hao's spirits, made the western zhi altar, sacrificed to the white emperor; his sacrificial animals used one dun colt, one yellow ox, one ram sheep each, it is said. Sixteen years later, Qin Wen Gong hunted east between the Qian and Wei, divined dwelling there and it was auspicious. Wen Gong dreamed of a yellow snake descending from heaven to earth, its mouth stopping at Fu Yan. Wen Gong asked Shi Dun; Dun said: 'This is the Supreme Deity's omen; my lord should sacrifice to it.' Thereupon he made the Fu zhi altar, using three sacrificial animals to perform suburban sacrifices to the white emperor.

Before the Fu zhi was made, beside Yong there were formerly the Wu Yang Wu zhi and Hao zhi to the east of Yong, all abandoned with no sacrifices. Some say: 'Since ancient times Yong province has been accumulated high, a secluded place of bright spirits; therefore zhi altars were established to suburb-sacrifice the Supreme Deity, and all the various spirit temples gathered there. Probably in Yellow Emperor's time they once conducted affairs there; even in the late Zhou they also performed suburban sacrifices there.' These words are not seen in the classics; noble scholars do not speak of them.

ä½œé„œç•¤å¾Œä¹å¹´ï¼Œæ–‡å…¬ç²è‹¥çŸ³é›²ï¼Œäºé™³å€‰åŒ—é˜ªåŸç¥ ä¹‹ã€‚ å…¶ç¥æˆ–æ­²ä¸è‡³ï¼Œæˆ–æ­²æ•¸ä¾†ï¼Œä¾†ä¹Ÿå¸¸ä»¥å¤œï¼Œå…‰è¼è‹¥æµæ˜Ÿï¼Œå¾æ±å—ä¾†é›†äºç¥ åŸï¼Œå‰‡è‹¥é›„é›ï¼Œå…¶è²æ®·é›²ï¼Œé‡é›å¤œé›Šã€‚ ä»¥ä¸€ç‰¢ç¥ ï¼Œå‘½æ›°é™³å¯¶ã€‚
Nine years after making the Fu zhi, Wen Gong obtained something like a stone cloud; he built a city on Chen Cang's north slope and sacrificed to it. Its spirit sometimes does not arrive for a year, sometimes comes several times a year; when it comes it is constantly at night, radiant like a shooting star, coming from the southeast to gather at the sacrifice city; then it is like a male chicken, its sound thunders like clouds, wild chickens crow at night. He sacrificed with one pen of sacrificial animals, naming it Chen Bao.

ä½œé„œç•¤å¾Œä¸ƒåå…«å¹´ï¼Œç§¦å¾·å…¬æ—¢ç«‹ï¼Œåœå±…é›ï¼Œã€Œå¾Œå­å­«é£²é¦¬æ–¼æ²³ã€ï¼Œé‚éƒ½é›ã€‚ é›ä¹‹è«¸ç¥ è‡ªæ­¤èˆˆã€‚ ç”¨ä¸‰ç™¾ç‰¢æ–¼é„œç•¤ã€‚ ä½œä¼ç¥ ã€‚ ç£”ç‹—é‚‘å››é–€ï¼Œä»¥å¾¡è ±è‘ã€‚
Seventy-eight years after making the Fu zhi, Qin De Gong was already established; he divined dwelling in Yong: 'later descendants will drink horses at the river'; then he made Yong the capital. Yong's various sacrifices arose from this time. He used three hundred pens of sacrificial animals at the Fu zhi. He made the Fu sacrifice. He tore dogs at the city's four gates to resist gu calamities.

De Gong died in his second year of establishment. Four years later, Qin Xuan Gong made the Mi zhi at Wei's south, sacrificing to the green emperor.

å…¶å¾Œåå››å¹´ï¼Œç§¦ç¹†å…¬ç«‹ï¼Œç—…è‡¥äº”æ—¥ä¸å¯¤ï¼› å¯¤ï¼Œä¹ƒè¨€å¤¢è¦‹ä¸Šå¸ï¼Œä¸Šå¸å‘½ç¹†å…¬å¹³æ™‰äº‚ã€‚ å²æ›¸è€Œè¨˜è—ä¹‹åºœã€‚ è€Œå¾Œä¸–çš†æ›°ç§¦ç¹†å…¬ä¸Šå¤©ã€‚
Fourteen years later, Qin Mu Gong was established; he was ill and lay unconscious for five days; he awoke and then said he dreamed he saw the Supreme Deity; the Supreme Deity commanded Mu Gong to pacify Jin's chaos. The scribe wrote it down and recorded it, storing it in the treasury. Yet later generations all said Qin Mu Gong ascended to heaven.

In Qin Mu Gong's ninth year on the throne, Qi Huan Gong was already hegemon; he assembled the feudal lords at Kui Qiu, and wished to perform feng and shan. Guan Zhong said: 'Ancient ones who performed feng on Mount Tai and shan on Liang Fu numbered seventy-two houses, and those Yi Wu recorded number twelve there. Formerly the Wu Huai clan performed feng on Mount Tai, shan on Yun Yun; Fu Xi performed feng on Mount Tai, shan on Yun Yun; Shen Nong performed feng on Mount Tai, shan on Yun Yun; Yan Di performed feng on Mount Tai, shan on Yun Yun; The Yellow Emperor performed feng on Mount Tai, shan on Ting Ting; Zhuan Xu performed feng on Mount Tai, shan on Yun Yun; Emperor Ku performed feng on Mount Tai, shan on Yun Yun; Yao performed feng on Mount Tai, shan on Yun Yun; Shun performed feng on Mount Tai, shan on Yun Yun; Yu performed feng on Mount Tai, shan on Hui Ji; Tang performed feng on Mount Tai, shan on Yun Yun; Zhou Cheng Wang performed feng on Mount Tai, shan on She Shou: all received the mandate before obtaining feng and shan.' Huan Gong said: 'I attacked the Shan Rong to the north, passed Gu Zhu; attacked Da Xia to the west, crossed the flowing sands, bound horses and hung chariots, ascended Bei Er mountain; attacked south to Zhao Ling, ascended Xiong Er mountain to gaze upon the Jiang and Han. There were three assemblies with war chariots, and six assemblies with carriages; nine times I united the feudal lords, once rectified all under heaven; no feudal lord opposed me. The former three dynasties received the mandate; how were they different?' Thereupon Guan Zhong saw that Huan Gong could not be convinced with words alone, so he explained using examples, saying: 'Ancient feng and shan used Xiang Shang's millet and Bei Li's grain as abundance; between the Jiang and Huai, one thatch with three ridges was used as the mat. The east sea offered fish with paired eyes, the west sea offered birds with paired wings; then there were fifteen kinds of things that came without being summoned. Now phoenix and qilin do not come, auspicious grains do not grow; instead cogon grass and sow thistle are luxuriant, horned owls arrive frequently; yet you wish to perform feng and shanâ€”is this not impossible?' Thereupon Huan Gong stopped. This year, Qin Mu Gong installed Jin's lord Yi Wu. After this, he established Jin's lords three times, pacifying their chaos. Mu Gong was established for thirty-nine years and then died.

Over a hundred years later, Confucius discussed the six arts; he transmitted briefly saying that those who changed surname and became king, who performed feng on Mount Tai and shan at Liang Fu, numbered over seventy kings; their sacrificial vessel rites were not clear, probably difficult to speak of. Someone asked about the explanation of the di sacrifice; Confucius said: 'I do not know. If one knows the explanation of the di sacrifice, it is as easy for him regarding all under heaven as regarding his palm.' The Shi says: When Zhou was in position and Wen Wang received the mandate, the government did not reach Mount Tai. Two years after Wu Wang conquered Yin, all under heaven was not yet peaceful when he died. Ah, it was during Cheng Wang that Zhou virtue pervaded; Cheng Wang's feng and shan then approached it. And later when attendant ministers governed, the Ji clan performed ceremonies at Mount Tai; Zhong Ni criticized this.

At this time Chang Hong served Zhou Ling Wang with techniques; no feudal lords paid court to Zhou, Zhou's strength was small; Chang Hong then clarified matters of ghosts and spirits, establishing the shooting of fox heads. The fox head ceremony was for feudal lords who did not come. He relied on monstrous things to attract the feudal lords. The feudal lords did not follow, and the Jin people seized and killed Chang Hong. Those among the Zhou people who spoke of techniques and monsters began with Chang Hong.

Over a hundred years later, Qin Ling Gong made the Wu Yang upper zhi, sacrificing to the yellow emperor; made the lower zhi, sacrificing to the Yan emperor.

Forty-eight years later, Zhou's grand scribe Dan saw Qin Xian Gong and said: 'Qin began united with Zhou; united yet separated; after five hundred years they should unite again; united for seventeen years and a hegemon king will emerge.' Gold rained at Que Yang; Qin Xian Gong considered he had obtained gold as an auspicious sign, therefore made the Qi zhi at Que Yang and sacrificed to the white emperor.

One hundred twenty years later Qin extinguished Zhou, and Zhou's nine tripods entered Qin. Some say the Song great Qiu altar perished, and the tripods submerged below Peng Cheng at the Si River.

ç§¦å§‹çš‡æ—¢å¹¶å¤©ä¸‹è€Œå¸ï¼Œæˆ–æ›°ï¼šã€Œé»ƒå¸å¾—åœŸå¾·ï¼Œé»ƒé¾åœ°è¾è¦‹ã€‚ å¤å¾—æœ¨å¾·ï¼Œé’é¾æ­¢æ–¼éƒŠï¼Œè‰æœ¨æš¢èŒ‚ã€‚ æ®·å¾—é‡‘å¾·ï¼ŒéŠ€è‡ªå±±æº¢ã€‚ å‘¨å¾—ç«å¾·ï¼Œæœ‰èµ¤çƒä¹‹ç¬¦ã€‚ ä»Šç§¦è®Šå‘¨ï¼Œæ°´å¾·ä¹‹æ™‚ã€‚ æ˜”ç§¦æ–‡å…¬å‡ºçµï¼Œç²é»‘é¾ï¼Œæ­¤å…¶æ°´å¾·ä¹‹ç‘ã€‚ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯ç§¦æ›´å‘½æ²³æ›°ã€Œå¾·æ°´ã€ï¼Œä»¥å†¬åæœˆç‚ºå¹´é¦–ï¼Œè‰²ä¸Šé»‘ï¼Œåº¦ä»¥å…­ç‚ºåï¼ŒéŸ³ä¸Šå¤§å‘‚ï¼Œäº‹çµ±ä¸Šæ³•ã€‚
Qin First Emperor, having united all under heaven and become emperor, some said: 'The Yellow Emperor obtained earth virtue; yellow dragons and earthworms appeared. Xia obtained wood virtue; green dragons stopped in the suburbs; grasses and woods were flourishing and luxuriant. Yin obtained metal virtue; silver overflowed from the mountains. Zhou obtained fire virtue; there was the tally of red crows. Now Qin succeeded Zhou; it was the time of water virtue. Formerly Qin Wen Gong went hunting and obtained a black dragon; this was its water virtue's auspicious sign.' Thereupon Qin renamed the Yellow River 'Virtue Water'; made the tenth winter month the year's beginning; valued black as the color; named measures with six; valued great Lu as the sound; unified affairs by valuing law.

å³å¸ä½ä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œæ±å·¡éƒ¡ç¸£ï¼Œç¥ é¨¶å¶§å±±ï¼Œé Œç§¦åŠŸæ¥­ã€‚ æ–¼æ˜¯å¾µå¾é½Šé­¯ä¹‹å„’ç”Ÿåšå£«ä¸ƒåäººï¼Œè‡³ä¹æ³°å±±ä¸‹ã€‚ è«¸å„’ç”Ÿæˆ–è­°æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤è€…å°ç¦ªç‚ºè’²è»Šï¼Œæƒ¡å‚·å±±ä¹‹åœŸçŸ³è‰æœ¨ï¼› åŸ½åœ°è€Œç¥­ï¼Œå¸­ç”¨è‘…ç¨­ï¼Œè¨€å…¶æ˜“éµä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ å§‹çš‡èæ­¤è­°å„ä¹–ç•°ï¼Œé›£æ–½ç”¨ï¼Œç”±æ­¤çµ€å„’ç”Ÿã€‚ è€Œé‚é™¤è»Šé“ï¼Œä¸Šè‡ªæ³°å±±é™½è‡³å·”ï¼Œç«‹çŸ³é Œç§¦å§‹çš‡å¸å¾·ï¼Œæ˜å…¶å¾—å°ä¹Ÿã€‚ å¾é™°é“ä¸‹ï¼Œç¦ªæ–¼æ¢çˆ¶ã€‚ å…¶ç¦®é —é‡‡å¤ªç¥ä¹‹ç¥€é›ä¸Šå¸æ‰€ç”¨ï¼Œè€Œå°è—çš†ç¥•ä¹‹ï¼Œä¸–ä¸å¾—è€Œè¨˜ä¹Ÿã€‚
Three years after ascending the emperor position, he inspected the eastern commanderies and counties, sacrificed at Zou Yi Mountain, and praised Qin's meritorious deeds. Thereupon he summoned and had Qi and Lu's ru scholars and erudites, seventy persons, follow him to below Mount Tai. Some of the ru scholars discussed and said: 'The ancient ones made cattail carts for feng and shan, hating to harm the mountain's soil, stones, grasses, and woods; swept the ground and sacrificed; mats used pickled straws; speaking of how easy they were to follow.' First Emperor heard these discussions were each divergent, difficult to apply and use; from this he demoted the ru scholars. Then he cleared a cart road, ascended from Mount Tai's southern side to the peak, erected a stone praising Qin First Emperor's virtue, clarifying that he obtained the feng. He descended by the northern road, performing shan at Liang Fu. Its rites rather adopted what the grand priest used in sacrificing to the Yong Supreme Deity; the feng burials were all kept secret, so generations could not record them.

å§‹çš‡ä¹‹ä¸Šæ³°å±±ï¼Œä¸­é˜ªé‡æš´é¢¨é›¨ï¼Œä¼‘æ–¼å¤§æ¨¹ä¸‹ã€‚ è«¸å„’ç”Ÿæ—¢çµ€ï¼Œä¸å¾—èˆ‡ç”¨æ–¼å°äº‹ä¹‹ç¦®ï¼Œèå§‹çš‡é‡é¢¨é›¨ï¼Œå‰‡è­ä¹‹ã€‚
When First Emperor ascended Mount Tai, on the middle slope he encountered violent wind and rain, and rested below a large tree. The various ru scholars, having been demoted, could not participate in the feng ceremony rites; when they heard First Emperor encountered wind and rain, they criticized it.

æ–¼æ˜¯å§‹çš‡é‚æ±éŠæµ·ä¸Šï¼Œè¡Œç¦®ç¥ åå±±å¤§å·åŠå…«ç¥ï¼Œæ±‚åƒŠäººç¾¨é–€ä¹‹å±¬ã€‚ å…«ç¥å°‡è‡ªå¤è€Œæœ‰ä¹‹ï¼Œæˆ–æ›°å¤ªå…¬ä»¥ä¾†ä½œä¹‹ã€‚ é½Šæ‰€ä»¥ç‚ºé½Šï¼Œä»¥å¤©é½Šä¹Ÿã€‚ å…¶ç¥€çµ•è«çŸ¥èµ·æ™‚ã€‚ å…«ç¥ï¼šä¸€æ›°å¤©ä¸»ï¼Œç¥ å¤©é½Šã€‚ å¤©é½Šæ·µæ°´ï¼Œå±…è‡¨è‘å—éƒŠå±±ä¸‹è€…ã€‚ äºŒæ›°åœ°ä¸»ï¼Œç¥ æ³°å±±æ¢çˆ¶ã€‚ è“‹å¤©å¥½é™°ï¼Œç¥ ä¹‹å¿…æ–¼é«˜å±±ä¹‹ä¸‹ï¼Œå°å±±ä¹‹ä¸Šï¼Œå‘½æ›°ã€Œç•¤ã€ï¼› åœ°è²´é™½ï¼Œç¥­ä¹‹å¿…æ–¼æ¾¤ä¸­åœœä¸˜äº‘ã€‚ ä¸‰æ›°å…µä¸»ï¼Œç¥ èš©å°¤ã€‚ èš©å°¤åœ¨æ±å¹³é™¸ç›£é„‰ï¼Œé½Šä¹‹è¥¿å¢ƒä¹Ÿã€‚ å››æ›°é™°ä¸»ï¼Œç¥ ä¸‰å±±ã€‚ äº”æ›°é™½ä¸»ï¼Œç¥ ä¹‹ç½˜ã€‚ å…­æ›°æœˆä¸»ï¼Œç¥ ä¹‹èŠå±±ã€‚ çš†åœ¨é½ŠåŒ—ï¼Œå¹¶å‹ƒæµ·ã€‚ ä¸ƒæ›°æ—¥ä¸»ï¼Œç¥ æˆå±±ã€‚ æˆå±±æ–—å…¥æµ·ï¼Œæœ€å±…é½Šæ±åŒ—éš…ï¼Œä»¥è¿æ—¥å‡ºäº‘ã€‚ å…«æ›°å››æ™‚ä¸»ï¼Œç¥ ç‘¯é‚ªã€‚ ç‘¯é‚ªåœ¨é½Šæ±æ–¹ï¼Œè“‹æ­²ä¹‹æ‰€å§‹ã€‚ çš†å„ç”¨ä¸€ç‰¢å…·ç¥ ï¼Œè€Œå·«ç¥æ‰€æç›Šï¼Œçªå¹£é›œç•°ç„‰ã€‚
Thereupon First Emperor toured east along the sea, performed rites and sacrificed to famous mountains, great rivers, and the eight spirits, seeking immortals of the Xianmen kind. The eight spirits have existed since ancient times; some say Tai Gong made them. Qi is called Qi because of heaven's Qi. Its sacrifices have ceased; no one knows when they began. The eight spirits: first, the heaven lord, sacrificed to heaven Qi. Heaven Qi is a deep pool of water that dwells below the mountain in Lin Zi's southern suburbs. Second, the earth lord, sacrificed to Mount Tai and Liang Fu. Probably heaven likes yin places; sacrifice to it certainly below high mountains and above small mountains, called 'zhi'; earth values yang places; sacrifice to it certainly in round mounds in the middle of marshes. Third, the soldiers lord, sacrificed to Chi You. Chi You is at Dong Ping Lu's Jian xiang, on Qi's western border. Fourth, the yin lord, sacrificed to the three mountains. Fifth, the yang lord, sacrificed to Chi Fu. Sixth, the moon lord, sacrificed to Lai Mountain. All are in Qi's north, bordering the Bo Sea. Seventh, the sun lord, sacrificed to Cheng Mountain. Cheng Mountain's handle enters the sea; it dwells farthest in Qi's northeast corner, to welcome the sun's rising. Eighth, the four seasons lord, sacrificed to Lang Ya. Lang Ya is in Qi's east; probably where the year begins. All each used one pen of sacrificial utensils to sacrifice; the wu zhu priests' additions and subtractions, jade coins and other things were mixed and different.

From Qi Wei and Xuan's time, Zou Zi's followers discussed and wrote about the cycles of the five virtues; when Qin became emperor, Qi people presented it, so First Emperor adopted it. Yet Song Wu Ji, Zheng Bo Qiao, Chong Shang, Xian Men Gaoâ€”all Yan people at the endâ€”made the fang immortal way, with form dissolution and melting change, depending on ghost and spirit affairs. Zou Yan became prominent among the feudal lords with yin and yang governing movement; yet Yan and Qi's seaside fang scholars transmitted his techniques but could not make them penetrate; thus the strange, circuitous, flattering, and expediently conforming followers arose from this, their number cannot be counted.

è‡ªå¨ã€å®£ã€ç‡•æ˜­ä½¿äººå…¥æµ·æ±‚è“¬èŠã€æ–¹ä¸ˆã€ç€›æ´²ã€‚ æ­¤ä¸‰ç¥å±±è€…ï¼Œå…¶å‚…åœ¨å‹ƒæµ·ä¸­ï¼Œå»äººä¸é ï¼› æ‚£ä¸”è‡³ï¼Œå‰‡èˆ¹é¢¨å¼•è€Œå»ã€‚ è“‹å˜—æœ‰è‡³è€…ï¼Œè«¸åƒŠäººåŠä¸æ­»ä¹‹è—¥çš†åœ¨ç„‰ã€‚ å…¶ç‰©ç¦½ç¸ç›¡ç™½ï¼Œè€Œé»ƒé‡‘éŠ€ç‚ºå®®é—•ã€‚ æœªè‡³ï¼Œæœ›ä¹‹å¦‚é›²ï¼› åŠåˆ°ï¼Œä¸‰ç¥å±±åå±…æ°´ä¸‹ã€‚ è‡¨ä¹‹ï¼Œé¢¨è¼’å¼•å»ï¼Œçµ‚è«èƒ½è‡³äº‘ã€‚ ä¸–ä¸»è«ä¸ç”˜å¿ƒç„‰ã€‚ åŠè‡³ç§¦å§‹çš‡å¹¶å¤©ä¸‹ï¼Œè‡³æµ·ä¸Šï¼Œå‰‡æ–¹å£«è¨€ä¹‹ä¸å¯å‹æ•¸ã€‚ å§‹çš‡è‡ªä»¥ç‚ºè‡³æµ·ä¸Šè€Œæä¸åŠçŸ£ï¼Œä½¿äººä¹ƒé½ç«¥ç”·å¥³å…¥æµ·æ±‚ä¹‹ã€‚ èˆ¹äº¤æµ·ä¸­ï¼Œçš†ä»¥é¢¨ç‚ºè§£ï¼Œæ›°æœªèƒ½è‡³ï¼Œæœ›è¦‹ä¹‹ç„‰ã€‚ å…¶æ˜å¹´ï¼Œå§‹çš‡å¾©æ¸¸æµ·ä¸Šï¼Œè‡³ç‘¯é‚ªï¼Œéæ’å±±ï¼Œå¾ä¸Šé»¨æ­¸ã€‚ å¾Œä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œæ¸¸ç¢£çŸ³ï¼Œè€ƒå…¥æµ·æ–¹å£«ï¼Œå¾ä¸Šéƒ¡æ­¸ã€‚ å¾Œäº”å¹´ï¼Œå§‹çš‡å—è‡³æ¹˜å±±ï¼Œé‚ç™»æœƒç¨½ï¼Œå¹¶æµ·ä¸Šï¼Œå†€é‡æµ·ä¸­ä¸‰ç¥å±±ä¹‹å¥‡è—¥ã€‚ ä¸å¾—ï¼Œé‚„è‡³æ²™ä¸˜å´©ã€‚
From Wei, Xuan, and Yan Zhao, they sent people into the sea to seek Peng Lai, Fang Zhang, and Ying Zhou. These three spirit mountains, according to the records, are in the middle of the Bo Sea, not far from people; when trouble was about to arrive, ships were blown by wind and led away. Probably some have once arrived; various immortals and medicines of immortality are all there. Its things, birds, and beasts are all white; palaces and halls are made of yellow gold and silver. Before arriving, when gazed at they are like clouds; when arrived at, the three spirit mountains instead dwell below the water. When approached, wind then led them away; in the end no one could arrive. No generation's lords were not sweet on the idea. And when Qin First Emperor united all under heaven and arrived at the seaside, then fang scholars spoke of it in numbers that could not be counted. First Emperor considered that having arrived at the seaside, he feared not reaching it; he sent people carrying boys and girls into the sea to seek it. Ships met in the middle of the sea; all used wind as an excuse, saying they could not yet arrive, but had gazed and seen it. The next year, First Emperor again toured the seaside, arrived at Lang Ya, passed Heng Mountain, and returned from Shang Dang. Three years later, he toured Jie Stone, examined the fang scholars who had entered the sea, and returned from Shang Commandery. Five years later, First Emperor went south to Xiang Mountain, then ascended Hui Ji, toured the seaside, hoping to encounter the marvelous medicines of the three spirit mountains in the sea. Not obtaining them, he returned and arrived at Sha Qiu, where he collapsed.

In Second Generation's first year, he inspected Jie Stone to the east, toured Hai's south, passed Mount Tai, arrived at Hui Ji; all performed rites and sacrificed; carved and engraved beside the stone writings First Emperor had established, to manifest First Emperor's meritorious virtue. That autumn, the feudal lords rebelled against Qin. Three years later Second Generation was assassinated and died.

å§‹çš‡å°ç¦ªä¹‹å¾ŒåäºŒæ­²ï¼Œç§¦äº¡ã€‚ è«¸å„’ç”Ÿç–¾ç§¦ç„šè©©æ›¸ï¼Œèª…åƒ‡æ–‡å­¸ï¼Œç™¾å§“æ€¨å…¶æ³•ï¼Œå¤©ä¸‹ç•”ä¹‹ï¼Œçš†è¨›æ›°ï¼šã€Œå§‹çš‡ä¸Šæ³°å±±ï¼Œç‚ºæš´é¢¨é›¨æ‰€æ“Šï¼Œä¸å¾—å°ç¦ªã€‚ã€ æ­¤è±ˆæ‰€è¬‚ç„¡å…¶å¾·è€Œç”¨äº‹è€…é‚ªï¼Ÿ
Twelve years after First Emperor's feng and shan, Qin perished. The various ru scholars hated Qin for burning the poetry and books, executing and punishing literature; the common people resented its laws; all under heaven rebelled against it; all falsely said: 'First Emperor ascended Mount Tai, was struck by violent wind and rain, could not perform feng and shan.' This is what is called one who had no virtue yet performed the rituals, right?

æ˜”ä¸‰ä»£ä¹‹ï¼ˆå›ï¼‰ï¼»å±…ï¼½çš†åœ¨æ²³æ´›ä¹‹é–’ï¼Œæ•…åµ©é«˜ç‚ºä¸­å¶½ï¼Œè€Œå››å¶½å„å¦‚å…¶æ–¹ï¼Œå››ç€†å’¸åœ¨å±±æ±ã€‚ è‡³ç§¦ç¨±å¸ï¼Œéƒ½å’¸é™½ï¼Œå‰‡äº”å¶½ã€å››ç€†çš†å¹¶åœ¨æ±æ–¹ã€‚ è‡ªäº”å¸ä»¥è‡³ç§¦ï¼Œè»¼èˆˆè»¼è¡°ï¼Œåå±±å¤§å·æˆ–åœ¨è«¸ä¾¯ï¼Œæˆ–åœ¨å¤©å­ï¼Œå…¶ç¦®æç›Šä¸–æ®Šï¼Œä¸å¯å‹è¨˜ã€‚ åŠç§¦å¹¶å¤©ä¸‹ï¼Œä»¤ç¥ å®˜æ‰€å¸¸å¥‰å¤©åœ°åå±±å¤§å·é¬¼ç¥å¯å¾—è€Œåºä¹Ÿã€‚
The former three dynasties' dwellings were all between the Yellow River and Luo; therefore Song Mountain is the central peak, and the four peaks each are in their directions, the four waterways all east of the mountains. When Qin became emperor and made Xian Yang the capital, then the five peaks and four waterways all united in the east. From the five emperors to Qin, they alternately rose and declined; famous mountains and great rivers were sometimes with feudal lords, sometimes with the Son of Heaven; their rites were diminished or increased differently in each generation, cannot all be recorded. And when Qin united all under heaven, it commanded the sacrifice officials what they constantly offered to heaven, earth, famous mountains, great rivers, ghosts, and spirits could be obtained and ordered.

Thereupon, east of Xiao: five famous mountains, two great rivers sacrificed to. Called Tai Shi. Tai Shi is Song Mountain. Heng Mountain, Mount Tai, Hui Ji, Xiang Mountain. The waters: Ji and Huai. In spring they used dried meat and wine for the year's sacrifice, because ice thawed; in autumn ice dried; in winter they blocked and prayed in sacrifice. Its sacrificial animals used one cow and one calf each; the pen utensils and jade coins were each different.

West of Hua: seven famous mountains, four famous rivers. Called Hua Mountain, Bo Mountain. Bo Mountain is Shuai Mountain. Yue Mountain, Qi Mountain, Wu Yue, Hong Zhong, Du Mountain. Du Mountain is Shu's Min Mountain. The waters: Yellow River, sacrificed at Lin Jin; Mian, sacrificed at Han Zhong; Jiu Yuan, sacrificed at Zhao Na; Jiang water, sacrificed at Shu. Yet the four great tombs Hong, Qi, Wu, Yue, all have tasted grain.

Yet Yong has the sun, moon, Shen, Chen, north and south dippers, Ying Huo, Tai Bai, year star, fill star, Chen star, twenty-eight lodges, wind earl, rain master, four seas, nine ministers, fourteen ministers, various spreads, various stricts, various qui and the likeâ€”over a hundred temples. The west also has several dozen sacrifices. At Hu there is a Zhou Son of Heaven temple. At Xia Gui there is a heaven spirit. Yong and Shi have Zhao Ming and the Son of Heaven's avoid pool. At Du and Bo there are the three altar lords' sacrifices and longevity star sacrifices; yet Yong's reed temple also has the Du lord. Only Yong's four zhi Supreme Deity is honored; the one whose light and shadow moves the people is only Chen Bao. Therefore Yong's four zhi: in spring they serve as the year's prayer, because ice thaws; in autumn ice dries; in winter they block sacrifice; in the fifth month they taste colts; and in the four mid months they perform monthly sacrifices; when Chen Bao festival comes, one sacrifice. In spring and summer they use red; in autumn and winter they use black. Zhi colts four horses, wooden yu dragon-ornament chariot one team, wooden yu chariot horses one team, each according to their emperor's color. Yellow calves and lambs each four, jade coins each have their number; all are buried alive, without sacrificial vessel utensils. Once every three years they perform the suburban sacrifice. Qin made the winter tenth month the year's beginning, therefore they constantly in the tenth month first night perform suburban seeing, pass the fire authority, bow beside Xian Yang, and value white clothing; its use is like regular sacrifice. The west zhi and Qi zhi are sacrificed to as formerly; the emperor does not personally go.

All these sacrifices are constantly governed by the grand priest, offered sacrifice according to the year's seasons. As for other famous mountains and rivers, various ghosts, and the eight spirits and the like: when the emperor passes by they sacrifice, when he leaves they stop. Spirit sacrifices in commanderies, counties, and distant places: the people each offer sacrifice themselves, not led by the Son of Heaven's wish officials. When the wish officials have secret wishes, then there are calamities or auspiciousness; they then wish and sacrifice to move the excess to below.

When Han rose, in Gao Zu's humble time, he once killed a great snake. Something said: 'The snake is the white emperor's son, yet the killer is the red emperor's son.' When Gao Zu first rose, he prayed at the Feng Fen Yu altar. He circled Pei, became Pei Gong, then sacrificed to Chi You, smeared the drums and banners. Then in the tenth month he arrived at Ba Shang, with the feudal lords pacified Xian Yang, and was established as Han king. Because of this they made the tenth month the year's beginning, and valued red as the color.

In the second year, he attacked Xiang Ji to the east and returned entering the pass, asking: 'In former Qin times, what emperor did the Supreme Deity sacrifices worship?' He answered: 'Four emperors; there are sacrifices to the white, blue, yellow, and red emperors.' Gao Zu said: 'I heard heaven has five emperors, yet there are fourâ€”what is this?' No one knew the explanation. Thereupon Gao Zu said: 'I know it nowâ€”it was waiting for me to complete the five.' Then he established a sacrifice to the black emperor, naming it the north zhi. The officials advanced the sacrifice; the emperor did not personally go. He summoned all the former Qin wish officials, again established the grand priest and grand steward, like their former ceremonies and rites. Because of this he commanded the county to serve as the duke altar. He issued an edict saying: 'I greatly value sacrifice and respectfully offer. Now the Supreme Deity's sacrifices and mountains, rivers, various spirits that should be sacrificed to: each with their proper time and rites sacrifice to them as formerly.'

After four years, when all under heaven was already settled, he edicted the censor, commanding Feng to carefully govern the Fen Yu altar, constantly in the four seasons and spring sacrificing to it with sheep and pigs. He commanded the wish officials to establish a sacrifice to Chi You at Chang An. Chang An established sacrificial wish officials and female shamans. Its Liang shamans sacrificed to heaven, earth, heaven altar, heaven water, the room's middle, hall above and the like; Jin shamans sacrificed to the five emperors, east lord, cloud middle lord, director of fate, shaman altar, shaman temple, clan people, first cooking and the like; Qin shamans sacrificed to the altar lord, shaman protector, clan entangled and the like; Jing shamans sacrificed to hall below, shaman ancestor, director of fate, Shi Mi and the like; Nine heavens shamans sacrificed to the nine heavens: all with the year's seasons sacrificed in the palace. Its Yellow River shamans sacrificed to the Yellow River at Lin Jin, while south mountain shamans sacrificed to south mountain in Qin. Qin Zhong was the Second Emperor. Each has its appointed time.

Two years later, some say the Zhou dynasty rose, established the city of Tai, and set up sacrifices to Hou Ji, who to this day receives offerings throughout the realm. æ˜¯æ­²ï¼Œåˆ¶æ›°ï¼šã€Œæœ•å³ä½åä¸‰å¹´äºä»Šï¼Œè³´å®—å»Ÿä¹‹éˆï¼Œç¤¾ç¨·ä¹‹ç¦ï¼Œæ–¹å…§è‰¾å®‰ï¼Œæ°‘äººé¡ç–¾ã€‚ é–’è€…æ¯”å¹´ç™»ï¼Œæœ•ä¹‹ä¸å¾·ï¼Œä½•ä»¥é¥—æ­¤ï¼Ÿ çš†ä¸Šå¸è«¸ç¥ä¹‹è³œä¹Ÿã€‚ è“‹èå¤è€…é¥—å…¶å¾·å¿…å ±å…¶åŠŸï¼Œæ¬²æœ‰å¢è«¸ç¥ç¥ ã€‚ æœ‰å¸è­°å¢é›äº”ç•¤è·¯è»Šå„ä¸€ä¹˜ï¼Œé§•è¢«å…·ï¼› è¥¿ç•¤ç•¦ç•¤ç¦ºè»Šå„ä¸€ä¹˜ï¼Œç¦ºé¦¬å››åŒ¹ï¼Œé§•è¢«å…·ï¼› å…¶æ²³ã€æ¹«ã€æ¼¢æ°´åŠ ç‰å„äºŒï¼› åŠè«¸ç¥ ï¼Œå„å¢å»£å£‡å ´ï¼Œçªå¹£ä¿è±†ä»¥å·®åŠ ä¹‹ã€‚ è€Œç¥ç¥•è€…æ­¸ç¦æ–¼æœ•ï¼Œç™¾å§“ä¸èˆ‡ç„‰ã€‚ è‡ªä»Šç¥è‡´æ•¬ï¼Œæ¯‹æœ‰æ‰€ç¥ˆã€‚ã€
That year, the decree stated: "I have now been on the throne thirteen years, relying on the spirits of the ancestral temples and the blessings of the Sheji, with peace and security within the borders and the people free from illness. Recently there have been good harvests year after year; given my lack of virtue, how can I enjoy such bounty? All of this is due to the blessings of the Supreme God and the various deities. I have heard that in ancient times, when one enjoyed virtue, one must repay merit, and so I wish to add to the sacrifices for the various deities. The officials proposed adding one chariot each to Yong's five zhi altars, complete with harnesses and coverings; For the Western Altar and Qi Altar, one yu chariot each with four yu horses, complete with harnesses and coverings; For the Yellow River, springs, and Han River, add two pieces of jade each; And for all the various sacrifices, expand and enlarge the altar grounds, adding gui tablets, bi silks, zu stands, and dou vessels according to their rank. And the priests who perform secret prayers shall direct blessings to Me; the common people shall not participate. From now on, let the priests offer respect without making any prayers."

é­¯äººå…¬å­«è‡£ä¸Šæ›¸æ›°ï¼šã€Œå§‹ç§¦å¾—æ°´å¾·ï¼Œä»Šæ¼¢å—ä¹‹ï¼Œæ¨çµ‚å§‹å‚³ï¼Œå‰‡æ¼¢ç•¶åœŸå¾·ï¼ŒåœŸå¾·ä¹‹æ‡‰é»ƒé¾è¦‹ã€‚ å®œæ”¹æ­£æœ”ï¼Œæ˜“æœè‰²ï¼Œè‰²ä¸Šé»ƒã€‚ã€ æ˜¯æ™‚ä¸ç›¸å¼µè’¼å¥½å¾‹æ­·ï¼Œä»¥ç‚ºæ¼¢ä¹ƒæ°´å¾·ä¹‹å§‹ï¼Œæ•…æ²³æ±ºé‡‘éš„ï¼Œå…¶ç¬¦ä¹Ÿã€‚ å¹´å§‹å†¬åæœˆï¼Œè‰²å¤–é»‘å…§èµ¤ï¼Œèˆ‡å¾·ç›¸æ‡‰ã€‚ å¦‚å…¬å­«è‡£è¨€ï¼Œéä¹Ÿã€‚ ç½·ä¹‹ã€‚ å¾Œä¸‰æ­²ï¼Œé»ƒé¾è¦‹æˆç´€ã€‚ æ–‡å¸ä¹ƒå¬å…¬å­«è‡£ï¼Œæ‹œç‚ºåšå£«ï¼Œèˆ‡è«¸ç”Ÿè‰æ”¹æ­·æœè‰²äº‹ã€‚ å…¶å¤ï¼Œä¸‹è©”æ›°ï¼šã€Œç•°ç‰©ä¹‹ç¥è¦‹äºæˆç´€ï¼Œç„¡å®³æ–¼æ°‘ï¼Œæ­²ä»¥æœ‰å¹´ã€‚ æœ•ç¥ˆéƒŠä¸Šå¸è«¸ç¥ï¼Œç¦®å®˜è­°ï¼Œç„¡è«±ä»¥å‹æœ•ã€‚ã€ æœ‰å¸çš†æ›°ã€Œå¤è€…å¤©å­å¤è¦ªéƒŠï¼Œç¥€ä¸Šå¸æ–¼éƒŠï¼Œæ•…æ›°éƒŠã€ã€‚ æ–¼æ˜¯å¤å››æœˆï¼Œæ–‡å¸å§‹éƒŠè¦‹é›äº”ç•¤ç¥ ï¼Œè¡£çš†ä¸Šèµ¤ã€‚
Gongsun Chen from Lu submitted a memorial: "Originally Qin possessed the water virtue; now Han inherits it. Following the cycle of the five virtues, Han should possess the earth virtue, and the sign of earth virtue is the appearance of a yellow dragon. We should reform the calendar, change the ritual colors, with yellow as the primary color." At this time, Chancellor Zhang Cang was fond of legal codes and calendars; he believed Han represented the beginning of the water virtue, which was why the Yellow River broke through the Golden Dikeâ€”this was its omen. The year begins in the tenth month of winter, with colors black outside and red inside, corresponding to the virtue. As Gongsun Chen said, it is not. He dismissed it. Three years later, a yellow dragon appeared at Chengji. Emperor Wen then summoned Gongsun Chen and appointed him as an erudite, having him and the other scholars draft proposals for reforming the calendar and ritual colors. That summer, he issued an edict: "A divine being in strange form appeared at Chengji; it brings no harm to the people, and the year will bring good harvests. I pray to the Supreme God and various deities in the suburbs; let the ritual officials deliberate without hesitation, even if it tires Me." All the officials said: "In ancient times, the emperor personally performed the suburban sacrifice in summer, offering sacrifices to the Supreme God in the suburbs, which is why it is called 'suburban'." Then in the fourth month of summer, Emperor Wen began performing the suburban sacrifice at Yong's five zhi altars, with all clothing in the upper red color.

The following year, Xin Yuang Ping from Zhao appeared before the emperor through his skill in observing vapors, saying: "To the northeast of Chang'an there is a divine aura forming five colors, like a tassel on a person's hat. Some say it is the dwelling place of divine spirits in the northeast, and the tomb of divine spirits in the west. A heavenly auspicious sign has descended; we should establish sacrifices to the Supreme God to match this omen." Then they built the Temple of the Five Emperors at Wei Yang, under the same roof, with one hall per emperor, each facing five gates, and each colored according to their emperor's virtue. The sacrificial implements and ceremonies were the same as those for Yong's five zhi altars.

å¤å››æœˆï¼Œæ–‡å¸è¦ªæ‹œéœ¸æ¸­ä¹‹æœƒï¼Œä»¥éƒŠè¦‹æ¸­é™½äº”å¸ã€‚ äº”å¸å»Ÿå—è‡¨æ¸­ï¼ŒåŒ—ç©¿è’²æ± æºæ°´ï¼Œæ¬Šç«èˆ‰è€Œç¥ ï¼Œè‹¥å…‰ç…‡ç„¶å±¬å¤©ç„‰ã€‚ æ–¼æ˜¯è²´å¹³ä¸Šå¤§å¤«ï¼Œè³œç´¯åƒé‡‘ã€‚ è€Œä½¿åšå£«è«¸ç”Ÿåˆºå…­ç¶“ä¸­ä½œç‹åˆ¶ï¼Œè¬€è­°å·¡ç‹©å°ç¦ªäº‹ã€‚
In the fourth month of summer, Emperor Wen personally performed the suburban sacrifice to the Five Emperors of Wei Yang at the meeting place of the Ba and Wei rivers. The Temple of the Five Emperors faced south toward the Wei River, pierced north through the waters of the Pu Pool ditch; torches were raised for the sacrifices, their light splendor seeming to connect with heaven. Then Ping was honored as an upper grand master and granted riches totaling a thousand pieces of gold. And he had the erudites and scholars excerpt from the Six Classics to compose royal regulations, discussing and deliberating matters of imperial tours and feng-shan sacrifices.

Emperor Wen exited through the Chang Gate and seemed to see five persons to the north of the road; following this direction, he established an altar to the Five Emperors straight to the north and sacrificed with five sets of livestock.

The following year, Xin Yuang Ping sent someone holding a jade cup and submitted a memorial at the palace gate offering it. Ping told the emperor: "There is an aura of precious jade coming toward the palace gate." When they inspected it, there was indeed someone offering a jade cup, engraved with the words "The ruler shall have extended longevity." Ping further said: "Your servant awaits the sun to culminate twice at noon." After a short time, the sun retreated and culminated again. Then he began changing the calendar to make the seventeenth year the first year, and ordered a great drinking feast throughout the empire.

Ping said: "The Zhou tripod was lost in the waters of the Si River; now the Yellow River has overflowed and connects with the Si. Someone submitted a memorial accusing Xin Yuang Ping of fabricating all the matters concerning vapors and spirits. Ping was handed over to the judicial officials for investigation, and Xin Yuang Ping was executed. After this, Emperor Wen became lax about matters of reforming the calendar, ritual colors, and divine spirits; the Five Emperors of Wei Yang and Chang Gate were overseen by sacrifice officials who performed the rituals at the proper times, but he did not go there himself.

In the first year, the Han dynasty had already risen for over sixty years; the world was peaceful and secure. The noble scholars all hoped the emperor would perform feng and shan sacrifices and reform the regulations. The emperor inclined toward Confucian teachings, summoned worthy men, and made Zhao Wan, Wang Zang, and others ministers based on their literary accomplishments, intending to discuss establishing an ancient-style Mingtang hall south of the city to receive the feudal lords. The drafted plans for imperial tours, feng-shan sacrifices, and changes to the calendar and ritual colors were not completed. It happened that Empress Dowager Dou governed according to Huang-Lao teachings and disliked Confucian arts; she sent people to secretly spy and obtained evidence of illicit dealings by Zhao Wan and others. She summoned and investigated Wan and Zang; Wan and Zang committed suicide, and all their undertakings were abolished.

Six years later, Empress Dowager Dou passed away. The following year, he summoned literary scholars like Gongsun Hong.

æ˜å¹´ï¼Œä»Šä¸Šåˆè‡³é›ï¼ŒéƒŠè¦‹äº”ç•¤ã€‚ å¾Œå¸¸ä¸‰æ­²ä¸€éƒŠã€‚ æ˜¯æ™‚ä¸Šæ±‚ç¥å›ï¼Œæ¨ä¹‹ä¸Šæ—ä¸­è¹„æ°è§€ã€‚ ç¥å›è€…ï¼Œé•·é™µå¥³å­ï¼Œä»¥å­æ­»ï¼Œè¦‹ç¥æ–¼å…ˆå¾Œå®›è‹¥ã€‚ å®›è‹¥ç¥ ä¹‹å…¶å®¤ï¼Œæ°‘å¤šå¾€ç¥ ã€‚ å¹³åŸå›å¾€ç¥ ï¼Œå…¶å¾Œå­å­«ä»¥å°Šé¡¯ã€‚ åŠä»Šä¸Šå³ä½ï¼Œå‰‡åšç¦®ç½®ç¥ ä¹‹å…§ä¸­ã€‚ èå…¶è¨€ï¼Œä¸è¦‹å…¶äººäº‘ã€‚
The following year, the current emperor first went to Yong and performed the suburban sacrifice to the five zhi altars. Thereafter, he regularly performed the suburban sacrifice once every three years. At this time, the emperor sought the Divine Lord and lodged her in the Ti Shi pavilion in the Shanglin Park. The Divine Lord was a woman from Changling who died in childbirth; she appeared as a spirit to her late husband Wan Ruo. Wan Ruo sacrificed to her in his chamber, and many people went to sacrifice there. The Lord of Pingyuan went to sacrifice there, and his descendants later became honored and eminent. When the current emperor ascended the throne, he established sacrifices to her in the inner palace with generous rites. One could hear her words but not see her person, they say.

æ˜¯æ™‚æå°‘å›äº¦ä»¥ç¥ ç¶ã€ç©€é“ã€å»è€æ–¹è¦‹ä¸Šï¼Œä¸Šå°Šä¹‹ã€‚ å°‘å›è€…ï¼Œæ•…æ·±æ¾¤ä¾¯èˆäººï¼Œä¸»æ–¹ã€‚ åŒ¿å…¶å¹´åŠå…¶ç”Ÿé•·ï¼Œå¸¸è‡ªè¬‚ä¸ƒåï¼Œèƒ½ä½¿ç‰©ï¼Œå»è€ã€‚ å…¶æ¸¸ä»¥æ–¹éè«¸ä¾¯ã€‚ ç„¡å¦»å­ã€‚ äººèå…¶èƒ½ä½¿ç‰©åŠä¸æ­»ï¼Œæ›´é¥‹éºä¹‹ï¼Œå¸¸é¤˜é‡‘éŒ¢è¡£é£Ÿã€‚ äººçš†ä»¥ç‚ºä¸æ²»ç”Ÿæ¥­è€Œé¥’çµ¦ï¼Œåˆä¸çŸ¥å…¶ä½•æ‰€äººï¼Œæ„ˆä¿¡ï¼Œçˆ­äº‹ä¹‹ã€‚ å°‘å›è³‡å¥½æ–¹ï¼Œå–„ç‚ºå·§ç™¼å¥‡ä¸­ã€‚ å˜—å¾æ­¦å®‰ä¾¯é£²ï¼Œåä¸­æœ‰ä¹åé¤˜è€äººï¼Œå°‘å›ä¹ƒè¨€èˆ‡å…¶å¤§çˆ¶æ¸¸å°„è™•ï¼Œè€äººç‚ºå…’æ™‚å¾å…¶å¤§çˆ¶ï¼Œè­˜å…¶è™•ï¼Œä¸€åç›¡é©šã€‚ å°‘å›è¦‹ä¸Šï¼Œä¸Šæœ‰æ•…éŠ…å™¨ï¼Œå•å°‘å›ã€‚ å°‘å›æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ­¤å™¨é½Šæ¡“å…¬åå¹´é™³æ–¼æŸå¯¢ã€‚ã€ å·²è€Œæ¡ˆå…¶åˆ»ï¼Œæœé½Šæ¡“å…¬å™¨ã€‚ ä¸€å®®ç›¡é§­ï¼Œä»¥ç‚ºå°‘å›ç¥ï¼Œæ•¸ç™¾æ­²äººä¹Ÿã€‚
At this time, Li Shaojun also appeared before the emperor with methods for sacrificing to the stove god, grain spirits, and dispelling old age, and the emperor honored him. Shaojun was a former retainer of the Marquis of Shenze and a master of esoteric methods. He concealed his age and background, constantly claiming to be seventy, able to manipulate objects and dispel old age. He traveled widely among the feudal lords with his esoteric methods. He had no wife or children. People heard of his ability to manipulate objects and achieve immortality, and moreover sent him gifts, so he constantly had surplus gold, money, clothing, and food. People all thought he did not manage any livelihood yet lived in abundance, and moreover did not know where he came from; they believed even more and competed to serve him. Shaojun was naturally fond of esoteric methods and skilled at making clever predictions that miraculously came true. Once while drinking with the Marquis of Wuan, there was a man over ninety in the company. Shaojun spoke of a place where he had played archery with the man's grandfather; the old man had followed his grandfather there as a child and recognized the place, astonishing everyone present. Shaojun appeared before the emperor; the emperor had an old bronze vessel and asked Shaojun about it. Shaojun said: "This vessel was displayed by Duke Huan of Qi in his cypress chamber in the tenth year." Then they examined the inscriptions, and indeed it was a vessel from Duke Huan of Qi's time. The entire palace was terrified, believing Shaojun to be divine, a man several hundred years old.

å°‘å›è¨€ä¸Šæ›°ï¼šã€Œç¥ ç¶å‰‡è‡´ç‰©ï¼Œè‡´ç‰©è€Œä¸¹æ²™å¯åŒ–ç‚ºé»ƒé‡‘ï¼Œé»ƒé‡‘æˆä»¥ç‚ºé£²é£Ÿå™¨å‰‡ç›Šå£½ï¼Œç›Šå£½è€Œæµ·ä¸­è“¬èŠåƒŠè€…ä¹ƒå¯è¦‹ï¼Œè¦‹ä¹‹ä»¥å°ç¦ªå‰‡ä¸æ­»ï¼Œé»ƒå¸æ˜¯ä¹Ÿã€‚ è‡£å˜—æ¸¸æµ·ä¸Šï¼Œè¦‹å®‰æœŸç”Ÿï¼Œå®‰æœŸç”Ÿé£Ÿå·¨æ£—ï¼Œå¤§å¦‚ç“œã€‚ å®‰æœŸç”ŸåƒŠè€…ï¼Œé€šè“¬èŠä¸­ï¼Œåˆå‰‡è¦‹äººï¼Œä¸åˆå‰‡éš±ã€‚ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯å¤©å­å§‹è¦ªç¥ ç¶ï¼Œé£æ–¹å£«å…¥æµ·æ±‚è“¬èŠå®‰æœŸç”Ÿä¹‹å±¬ï¼Œè€Œäº‹åŒ–ä¸¹æ²™è«¸è—¥é½Šç‚ºé»ƒé‡‘çŸ£ã€‚
Shaojun told the emperor: "By sacrificing to the stove god one can summon spirits; once spirits are summoned, cinnabar and sand can be transformed into gold. When gold is formed and made into eating and drinking vessels, it increases longevity. With increased longevity, the immortals of Penglai in the sea can be seen; seeing them and performing feng-shan sacrifices leads to immortality, as was the case with the Yellow Emperor. Your servant once traveled on the sea and saw An Qisheng; An Qisheng ate giant dates as large as melons." An Qisheng is an immortal who communicates with Penglai; when conditions are right he appears to people, when not, he hides." Then the emperor began personally sacrificing to the stove god, sent alchemists into the sea to seek An Qisheng and others of Penglai, and engaged in the practice of transforming cinnabar, sand, and various medicines into gold.

å±…ä¹…ä¹‹ï¼Œæå°‘å›ç—…æ­»ã€‚ å¤©å­ä»¥ç‚ºåŒ–å»ä¸æ­»ï¼Œè€Œä½¿é»ƒéŒ˜å²å¯¬èˆ’å—å…¶æ–¹ã€‚ æ±‚è“¬èŠå®‰æœŸç”Ÿè«èƒ½å¾—ï¼Œè€Œæµ·ä¸Šç‡•é½Šæ€ªè¿‚ä¹‹æ–¹å£«å¤šæ›´ä¾†è¨€ç¥äº‹çŸ£ã€‚
After a long time, Li Shaojun fell ill and died. The emperor believed he had transformed and ascended to immortality, and had the official Kuanshu of the Yellow Hammer receive his methods. They sought An Qisheng of Penglai but could not find him, and many more alchemists from the seacoast regions of Yan and Qi, with their strange and circuitous ways, came to speak of divine matters.

äº³äººè¬¬å¿Œå¥ç¥ å¤ªä¸€æ–¹ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤©ç¥è²´è€…å¤ªä¸€ï¼Œå¤ªä¸€ä½æ›°äº”å¸ã€‚ å¤è€…å¤©å­ä»¥æ˜¥ç§‹ç¥­å¤ªä¸€æ±å—éƒŠï¼Œç”¨å¤ªç‰¢ï¼Œä¸ƒæ—¥ï¼Œç‚ºå£‡é–‹å…«é€šä¹‹é¬¼é“ã€‚ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯å¤©å­ä»¤å¤ªç¥ç«‹å…¶ç¥ é•·å®‰æ±å—éƒŠï¼Œå¸¸å¥‰ç¥ å¦‚å¿Œæ–¹ã€‚ å…¶å¾Œäººæœ‰ä¸Šæ›¸ï¼Œè¨€ã€Œå¤è€…å¤©å­ä¸‰å¹´å£¹ç”¨å¤ªç‰¢ç¥ ç¥ä¸‰ä¸€ï¼šå¤©ä¸€ã€åœ°ä¸€ã€å¤ªä¸€ã€ã€‚ å¤©å­è¨±ä¹‹ï¼Œä»¤å¤ªç¥é ˜ç¥ ä¹‹æ–¼å¿Œå¤ªä¸€å£‡ä¸Šï¼Œå¦‚å…¶æ–¹ã€‚ å¾Œäººå¾©æœ‰ä¸Šæ›¸ï¼Œè¨€ã€Œå¤è€…å¤©å­å¸¸ä»¥æ˜¥è§£ç¥ ï¼Œç¥ é»ƒå¸ç”¨ä¸€æ¢Ÿç ´é¡ï¼› å†¥ç¾Šç”¨ç¾Šç¥ ï¼› é¦¬è¡Œç”¨ä¸€é’ç‰¡é¦¬ï¼› å¤ªä¸€ã€æ¾¤å±±å›åœ°é•·ç”¨ç‰›ï¼› æ­¦å¤·å›ç”¨ä¹¾é­šï¼› é™°é™½ä½¿è€…ä»¥ä¸€ç‰›ã€ã€‚ ä»¤ç¥ å®˜é ˜ä¹‹å¦‚å…¶æ–¹ï¼Œè€Œç¥ æ–¼å¿Œå¤ªä¸€å£‡æ—ã€‚
Miao Ji from Bo submitted a memorial on methods for sacrificing to Tai Yi: "The most honored of the heavenly spirits is Tai Yi, and Tai Yi's assistants are called the Five Emperors. In ancient times, the emperor sacrificed to Tai Yi in the southeast suburb during spring and autumn, using great livestock offerings, for seven days, and made an altar that opened eight paths for the ghosts." Then the emperor ordered the Grand Priest to establish these sacrifices in the southeast suburb of Chang'an, and regularly perform them according to Ji's methods. After this, someone submitted a memorial saying: "In ancient times, the emperor once every three years used great livestock to sacrifice to the three supreme spirits: Heaven One, Earth One, and Tai Yi." The emperor approved this and ordered the Grand Priest to oversee sacrifices to them on Ji's Tai Yi altar, according to their methods. Later people again submitted a memorial saying: "In ancient times, the emperor constantly performed the spring solution sacrifices, sacrificing to the Yellow Emperor with one owl and a broken mirror; To the Dark Sheep with sheep sacrifices; To the Horse Travel with one blue stallion; To Tai Yi, the Lord of Ze Mountain, and Earth Length with oxen; To the Lord of Wuyi with dried fish; To the yin-yang messengers with one ox." He ordered the sacrifice officials to oversee them according to their methods, and sacrifices were performed beside Ji's Tai Yi altar.

After this, a white deer appeared in the emperor's park; he used its hide to make currency to issue auspicious omens, and created white gold coins.

å…¶æ˜å¹´ï¼ŒéƒŠé›ï¼Œç²ä¸€è§’ç¸ï¼Œè‹¥éºƒç„¶ã€‚ æœ‰å¸æ›°ï¼šã€Œé™›ä¸‹è‚…ç¥—éƒŠç¥€ï¼Œä¸Šå¸å ±äº«ï¼ŒéŒ«ä¸€è§’ç¸ï¼Œè“‹éºŸäº‘ã€‚ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯ä»¥è–¦äº”ç•¤ï¼Œç•¤åŠ ä¸€ç‰›ä»¥ç‡ã€‚ éŒ«è«¸ä¾¯ç™½é‡‘ï¼Œé¢¨ç¬¦æ‡‰åˆäºå¤©ä¹Ÿã€‚
The following year, during the suburban sacrifice at Yong, they obtained a one-horned beast that resembled a muntjac. The officials said: "Your Majesty has conducted the suburban sacrifice with solemn reverence; the Supreme God has responded favorably and granted a one-horned beast, which is probably a qilin." Then he used it to make offerings at the five zhi altars, adding one ox to each for the burnt offering. He granted white gold to the feudal lords, instructing that the omens and responses should accord with heaven.

æ–¼æ˜¯æ¿ŸåŒ—ç‹ä»¥ç‚ºå¤©å­ä¸”å°ç¦ªï¼Œä¹ƒä¸Šæ›¸ç»å¤ªå±±åŠå…¶æ—é‚‘ï¼Œå¤©å­ä»¥ä»–ç¸£å„Ÿä¹‹ã€‚ å¸¸å±±ç‹æœ‰ç½ªï¼Œé·ï¼Œå¤©å­å°å…¶å¼Ÿæ–¼çœŸå®šï¼Œä»¥çºŒå…ˆç‹ç¥€ï¼Œè€Œä»¥å¸¸å±±ç‚ºéƒ¡ï¼Œç„¶å¾Œäº”å²³çš†åœ¨å¤©å­ä¹‹ï¼ˆé‚¦ï¼‰ï¼»éƒ¡ï¼½ã€‚
Then the King of Jibei, believing the emperor was about to perform feng and shan sacrifices, submitted a memorial offering Mount Tai and its neighboring settlements; the emperor compensated him with other counties. The King of Changshan committed a crime and was moved; the emperor enfeoffed his younger brother at Zhending to continue the sacrifices to the previous king, and made Changshan a commandery, so that all five sacred mountains came under the emperor's [commanderies].

å…¶æ˜å¹´ï¼Œé½Šäººå°‘ç¿ä»¥é¬¼ç¥æ–¹è¦‹ä¸Šã€‚ ä¸Šæœ‰æ‰€å¹¸ç‹å¤«äººï¼Œå¤«äººå’ï¼Œå°‘ç¿ä»¥æ–¹è“‹å¤œè‡´ç‹å¤«äººåŠç¶é¬¼ä¹‹è²Œäº‘ï¼Œå¤©å­è‡ªå¸·ä¸­æœ›è¦‹ç„‰ã€‚ æ–¼æ˜¯ä¹ƒæ‹œå°‘ç¿ç‚ºæ–‡æˆå°‡è»ï¼Œè³è³œç”šå¤šï¼Œä»¥å®¢ç¦®ç¦®ä¹‹ã€‚ æ–‡æˆè¨€æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸Šå³æ¬²èˆ‡ç¥é€šï¼Œå®®å®¤è¢«æœéè±¡ç¥ï¼Œç¥ç‰©ä¸è‡³ã€‚ã€ ä¹ƒä½œç•«é›²æ°£è»Šï¼ŒåŠå„ä»¥å‹æ—¥é§•è»Šè¾Ÿæƒ¡é¬¼ã€‚ åˆä½œç”˜æ³‰å®®ï¼Œä¸­ç‚ºè‡ºå®¤ï¼Œç•«å¤©ã€åœ°ã€å¤ªä¸€è«¸é¬¼ç¥ï¼Œè€Œç½®ç¥­å…·ä»¥è‡´å¤©ç¥ã€‚ å±…æ­²é¤˜ï¼Œå…¶æ–¹ç›Šè¡°ï¼Œç¥ä¸è‡³ã€‚ ä¹ƒç‚ºå¸›æ›¸ä»¥é£¯ç‰›ï¼Œè©³ä¸çŸ¥ï¼Œè¨€æ›°æ­¤ç‰›è…¹ä¸­æœ‰å¥‡ã€‚ æ®ºè¦–å¾—æ›¸ï¼Œæ›¸è¨€ç”šæ€ªã€‚ å¤©å­è­˜å…¶æ‰‹æ›¸ï¼Œå•å…¶äººï¼Œæœæ˜¯å½æ›¸ï¼Œæ–¼æ˜¯èª…æ–‡æˆå°‡è»ï¼Œéš±ä¹‹ã€‚
The following year, Shao Weng from Qi appeared before the emperor with methods for communicating with ghosts and spirits. The emperor had a favored consort Lady Wang who died; Shao Weng used his methods to secretly summon the appearances of Lady Wang and the stove ghost at night, they say, and the emperor saw them from behind his curtain. Then he appointed Shao Weng as General Wencheng, granting him many rewards and treating him with the rites due a guest. Wencheng said: "If the emperor wishes to communicate with the spirits, his palace chambers and clothing must imitate the spirits, otherwise spirit beings will not come." Then he had painted chariots made that resembled cloud vapors, and had them driven on auspicious days to ward off evil spirits. He also built the Ganquan Palace, with platform chambers in the middle painted with heaven, earth, Tai Yi, and various ghosts and spirits, and placed sacrificial implements to summon heavenly spirits. After more than a year, his methods grew increasingly ineffective, and the spirits did not come. Then he made a document on silk and fed it to an ox, pretending not to know, and said that there was something strange in the ox's belly. They killed and examined the ox, obtaining the document, which spoke of very strange things. The emperor recognized his handwriting and questioned him; indeed it was a forged document, so he executed General Wencheng but kept it secret.

After this, he also built the Bai Liang pavilion, copper pillars, dew-catching immortal figures, and the like.

æ–‡æˆæ­»æ˜å¹´ï¼Œå¤©å­ç—…é¼æ¹–ç”šï¼Œå·«é†«ç„¡æ‰€ä¸è‡´ï¼Œä¸æ„ˆã€‚ æ¸¸æ°´ç™¼æ ¹è¨€ä¸Šéƒ¡æœ‰å·«ï¼Œç—…è€Œé¬¼ç¥ä¸‹ä¹‹ã€‚ ä¸Šå¬ç½®ç¥ ä¹‹ç”˜æ³‰ã€‚ åŠç—…ï¼Œä½¿äººå•ç¥å›ã€‚ ç¥å›è¨€æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤©å­ç„¡æ†‚ç—…ã€‚ ç—…å°‘æ„ˆï¼Œå½Šèˆ‡æˆ‘æœƒç”˜æ³‰ã€‚ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯ç—…æ„ˆï¼Œé‚èµ·ï¼Œå¹¸ç”˜æ³‰ï¼Œç—…è‰¯å·²ã€‚ å¤§èµ¦ï¼Œç½®å£½å®®ç¥å›ã€‚ å£½å®®ç¥å›æœ€è²´è€…å¤ªä¸€ï¼Œå…¶ä½æ›°å¤§ç¦ã€å¸å‘½ä¹‹å±¬ï¼Œçš†å¾ä¹‹ã€‚ éå¯å¾—è¦‹ï¼Œèå…¶è¨€ï¼Œè¨€èˆ‡äººéŸ³ç­‰ã€‚ æ™‚å»æ™‚ä¾†ï¼Œä¾†å‰‡é¢¨è‚…ç„¶ã€‚ å±…å®¤å¸·ä¸­ã€‚ æ™‚æ™è¨€ï¼Œç„¶å¸¸ä»¥å¤œã€‚ å¤©å­ç¥“ï¼Œç„¶å¾Œå…¥ã€‚ å› å·«ç‚ºä¸»äººï¼Œé—œé£²é£Ÿã€‚ æ‰€ä»¥è¨€ï¼Œè¡Œä¸‹ã€‚ åˆç½®å£½å®®ã€åŒ—å®®ï¼Œå¼µç¾½æ——ï¼Œè¨­ä¾›å…·ï¼Œä»¥ç¦®ç¥å›ã€‚ ç¥å›æ‰€è¨€ï¼Œä¸Šä½¿äººå—æ›¸å…¶è¨€ï¼Œå‘½ä¹‹æ›°ã€Œç•«æ³•ã€ã€‚ å…¶æ‰€èªï¼Œä¸–ä¿—ä¹‹æ‰€çŸ¥ä¹Ÿï¼Œç„¡çµ•æ®Šè€…ï¼Œè€Œå¤©å­å¿ƒç¨å–œã€‚ å…¶äº‹ç¥•ï¼Œä¸–è«çŸ¥ä¹Ÿã€‚
The year after Wencheng's death, the emperor fell gravely ill at Dinghu; he summoned shamans and doctors of every kind, but was not healed. You Shuifa Gen said that in Shang commandery there was a shaman who, when ill, had ghosts and spirits descend to her. The emperor summoned her and established sacrifices to her at Ganquan. When he fell ill, he sent someone to consult the Divine Lord. The Divine Lord said: "The emperor need not worry about his illness. When his illness improves slightly, force yourself to meet with me at Ganquan." Then his illness was cured; he rose and visited Ganquan, where his illness was completely healed. He declared a great amnesty and established the Divine Lord in the Longevity Palace. In the Longevity Palace, the most honored divine lord was Tai Yi, whose assistants were called the Great Prohibition, Director of Fate, and the like, all of whom followed her. She could not be seen, but one could hear her words, which sounded just like a human voice. She sometimes left and sometimes came; when she came, there was a solemn wind. She dwelt within the curtains of the chamber. She sometimes spoke during the day, but constantly at night. The emperor purified himself, then entered. He had the shaman act as hostess and manage the food and drink. Whatever she spoke of was carried out below. He also established the Longevity Palace and North Palace, spread feather flags, and set up offering implements to honor the Divine Lord. The emperor had someone receive and record the Divine Lord's words, calling them the "Painting Methods." What she spoke of was common worldly knowledge, nothing extraordinarily unusual, yet the emperor's heart was uniquely delighted. Her affairs were secret; the world knew nothing of them.

Three years later, the officials said that the yuan should be named according to heavenly auspicious signs, not by numbering them as one and two. The first yuan was called "Build," the second yuan with the comet was called "Light," and the third yuan with the suburban one-horned beast was called "Hunt," they said.

å…¶æ˜å¹´å†¬ï¼Œå¤©å­éƒŠé›ï¼Œè­°æ›°ï¼šã€Œä»Šä¸Šå¸æœ•è¦ªéƒŠï¼Œè€Œå¾ŒåœŸç„¡ç¥€ï¼Œå‰‡ç¦®ä¸ç­”ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ æœ‰å¸èˆ‡å¤ªå²å…¬ã€ç¥ å®˜å¯¬èˆ’è­°ï¼šã€Œå¤©åœ°ç‰²è§’ç¹­æ —ã€‚ ä»Šé™›ä¸‹è¦ªç¥ ååœŸï¼ŒååœŸå®œæ–¼æ¾¤ä¸­åœœä¸˜ç‚ºäº”å£‡ï¼Œå£‡ä¸€é»ƒçŠ¢å¤ªç‰¢å…·ï¼Œå·²ç¥ ç›¡ç˜ï¼Œè€Œå¾ç¥ è¡£ä¸Šé»ƒã€‚ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯å¤©å­é‚æ±ï¼Œå§‹ç«‹ååœŸç¥ æ±¾é™°è„½ä¸˜ï¼Œå¦‚å¯¬èˆ’ç­‰è­°ã€‚ ä¸Šè¦ªæœ›æ‹œï¼Œå¦‚ä¸Šå¸ç¦®ã€‚ ç¦®ç•¢ï¼Œå¤©å­é‚è‡³æ»é™½è€Œé‚„ã€‚ éé›’é™½ï¼Œä¸‹è©”æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸‰ä»£é‚ˆçµ•ï¼Œé çŸ£é›£å­˜ã€‚ å…¶ä»¥ä¸‰åé‡Œåœ°å°å‘¨å¾Œç‚ºå‘¨å­å—å›ï¼Œä»¥å¥‰å…¶å…ˆç¥€ç„‰ã€‚ã€ æ˜¯æ­²ï¼Œå¤©å­å§‹å·¡éƒ¡ç¸£ï¼Œä¾µå°‹æ–¼æ³°å±±çŸ£ã€‚
The following winter, the emperor performed the suburban sacrifice at Yong and discussed: "Now I personally sacrifice to the Supreme God in the suburbs, but Hou Tu has no sacrifices; this makes the rites unbalanced." The officials discussed with the Grand Historian and sacrifice official Kuanshu: "For heaven and earth, the sacrificial animals have horns like silkworm cocoons and chestnuts. Now Your Majesty personally sacrifices to Hou Tu; Hou Tu should have five altars in a round mound in the marshes, each altar with one yellow calf and complete great livestock offerings; after the sacrifice, bury everything completely, and the sacrificial clothing should be yellow above." Then the emperor went east and began establishing the Hou Tu sacrifice at the Wei Qiu in Fen Yin, as Kuanshu and the others had discussed. The emperor personally gazed and bowed, following the same rites as for the Supreme God. When the rites were completed, the emperor then went to Xing Yang and returned. Passing through Luoyang, he issued an edict: "The Three Dynasties are long gone and distant; it is difficult to preserve them. I shall enfeoff the Zhou descendants with thirty li of land as the Lord of Zhou Zi Nan, to maintain their ancestral sacrifices there." That year, the emperor began touring the commanderies and counties, gradually approaching Mount Tai.

å…¶æ˜¥ï¼Œæ¨‚æˆä¾¯ä¸Šæ›¸è¨€æ¬’å¤§ã€‚ æ¬’å¤§ï¼Œè† æ±å®®äººï¼Œæ•…å˜—èˆ‡æ–‡æˆå°‡è»åŒå¸«ï¼Œå·²è€Œç‚ºè† æ±ç‹å°šæ–¹ã€‚ è€Œæ¨‚æˆä¾¯å§Šç‚ºåº·ç‹åï¼Œç„¡å­ã€‚ åº·ç‹æ­»ï¼Œä»–å§¬å­ç«‹ç‚ºç‹ã€‚ è€Œåº·åæœ‰æ·«è¡Œï¼Œèˆ‡ç‹ä¸ç›¸ä¸­ï¼Œç›¸å±ä»¥æ³•ã€‚ åº·åèæ–‡æˆå·²æ­»ï¼Œè€Œæ¬²è‡ªåªšæ–¼ä¸Šï¼Œä¹ƒé£æ¬’å¤§å› æ¨‚æˆä¾¯æ±‚è¦‹è¨€æ–¹ã€‚ å¤©å­æ—¢èª…æ–‡æˆï¼Œå¾Œæ‚”å…¶èš¤æ­»ï¼Œæƒœå…¶æ–¹ä¸ç›¡ï¼ŒåŠè¦‹æ¬’å¤§ï¼Œå¤§èªªã€‚ å¤§ç‚ºäººé•·ç¾ï¼Œè¨€å¤šæ–¹ç•¥ï¼Œè€Œæ•¢ç‚ºå¤§è¨€è™•ä¹‹ä¸ç–‘ã€‚ å¤§è¨€æ›°ï¼šã€Œè‡£å¸¸å¾€ä¾†æµ·ä¸­ï¼Œè¦‹å®‰æœŸã€ç¾¨é–€ä¹‹å±¬ã€‚ é¡§ä»¥è‡£ç‚ºè³¤ï¼Œä¸ä¿¡è‡£ã€‚ åˆä»¥ç‚ºåº·ç‹è«¸ä¾¯è€³ï¼Œä¸è¶³èˆ‡æ–¹ã€‚ è‡£æ•¸è¨€åº·ç‹ï¼Œåº·ç‹åˆä¸ç”¨è‡£ã€‚ è‡£ä¹‹å¸«æ›°ï¼šã€é»ƒé‡‘å¯æˆï¼Œè€Œæ²³æ±ºå¯å¡ï¼Œä¸æ­»ä¹‹è—¥å¯å¾—ï¼ŒåƒŠäººå¯è‡´ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ ç„¶è‡£ææ•ˆæ–‡æˆï¼Œå‰‡æ–¹å£«çš†å¥„å£ï¼Œæƒ¡æ•¢è¨€æ–¹å“‰ï¼ã€ ä¸Šæ›°ï¼šã€Œæ–‡æˆé£Ÿé¦¬è‚æ­»è€³ã€‚ å­èª èƒ½ä¿®å…¶æ–¹ï¼Œæˆ‘ä½•æ„›ä¹ï¼ã€ å¤§æ›°ï¼šã€Œè‡£å¸«éæœ‰æ±‚äººï¼Œäººè€…æ±‚ä¹‹ã€‚ é™›ä¸‹å¿…æ¬²è‡´ä¹‹ï¼Œå‰‡è²´å…¶ä½¿è€…ï¼Œä»¤æœ‰è¦ªå±¬ï¼Œä»¥å®¢ç¦®å¾…ä¹‹ï¼Œå‹¿å‘ï¼Œä½¿å„ä½©å…¶ä¿¡å°ï¼Œä¹ƒå¯ä½¿é€šè¨€æ–¼ç¥äººã€‚ ç¥äººå°šè‚¯é‚ªä¸é‚ªã€‚ è‡´å°Šå…¶ä½¿ï¼Œç„¶å¾Œå¯è‡´ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯ä¸Šä½¿é©—å°æ–¹ï¼Œé¬¬æ£‹ï¼Œæ£‹è‡ªç›¸è§¸æ“Šã€‚
That spring, the Marquis of Yuecheng submitted a memorial speaking of Luan Da. Luan Da was a palace attendant from Jiaodong; he had once studied under the same teacher as General Wencheng, and later became the director of crafts for the King of Jiaodong. The Marquis of Yuecheng's elder sister was Queen to King Kang and had no children. When King Kang died, a son from another concubine was established as king. Queen Kang had licentious conduct and was not on good terms with the king; they threatened each other with legal action. Queen Kang heard that Wencheng had died and wished to curry favor with the emperor, so she sent Luan Da through the Marquis of Yuecheng to seek an audience and speak of his methods. The emperor had executed Wencheng but later regretted his premature death and lamented that his methods were not fully obtained; when he saw Luan Da, he was greatly delighted. Da was tall and handsome, his speech full of strategies, and he dared to make grand statements and handle matters without hesitation. Da said: "Your servant constantly travels in the seas and has seen An Qi, Xian Men, and the like. But they considered your servant too lowly and did not believe me. They also thought King Kang was merely a feudal lord and not worth sharing methods with. Your servant repeatedly spoke to King Kang, but King Kang would not employ me. My teacher said: 'Gold can be created, the Yellow River breach can be sealed, immortal medicine can be obtained, and immortals can be summoned.' But your servant feared following Wencheng's example, for then all alchemists would keep their mouths shutâ€”who would dare speak of methods anymore!" The emperor said: "Wencheng only died from eating horse liver. If you can truly practice his methods, what would I hold back!" Da said: "My teacher did not seek out people; people sought him. If Your Majesty must summon him, then honor his envoys, give them relatives, treat them with the rites due guests, do not demean them, and have each wear their seal of trust; only then can they communicate with the divine beings. Whether the divine beings will be willing or not. Summon them by honoring their envoys; only then can they be summoned." Then the emperor had him test small methods; the fighting chess pieces moved and struck each other on their own.

æ˜¯æ™‚ä¸Šæ–¹æ†‚æ²³æ±ºï¼Œè€Œé»ƒé‡‘ä¸å°±ï¼Œä¹ƒæ‹œå¤§ç‚ºäº”åˆ©å°‡è»ã€‚ å±…æœˆé¤˜ï¼Œå¾—å››å°ï¼Œä½©å¤©å£«å°‡è»ã€åœ°å£«å°‡è»ã€å¤§é€šå°‡è»å°ã€‚ åˆ¶è©”å¾¡å²ï¼šã€Œæ˜”ç¦¹ç–ä¹æ±Ÿï¼Œæ±ºå››ç€†ã€‚ é–’è€…æ²³æº¢çš‹é™¸ï¼Œéš„ç¹‡ä¸æ¯ã€‚ æœ•è‡¨å¤©ä¸‹äºŒåæœ‰å…«å¹´ï¼Œå¤©è‹¥éºæœ•å£«è€Œå¤§é€šç„‰ã€‚ ä¹¾ç¨±ã€èœšé¾ã€ï¼Œã€é´»æ¼¸äºèˆ¬ã€ï¼Œæœ•æ„åº¶å¹¾èˆ‡ç„‰ã€‚ å…¶ä»¥äºŒåƒæˆ¶å°åœ°å£«å°‡è»å¤§ç‚ºæ¨‚é€šä¾¯ã€‚ã€ è³œåˆ—ä¾¯ç”²ç¬¬ï¼Œåƒ®åƒäººã€‚ ä¹˜è½æ–¥è»Šé¦¬å¸·å¹„å™¨ç‰©ä»¥å……å…¶å®¶ã€‚ åˆä»¥è¡›é•·å…¬ä¸»å¦»ä¹‹ï¼Œé½é‡‘è¬æ–¤ï¼Œæ›´å‘½å…¶é‚‘æ›°ç•¶åˆ©å…¬ä¸»ã€‚ å¤©å­è¦ªå¦‚äº”åˆ©ä¹‹ç¬¬ã€‚ ä½¿è€…å­˜å•ä¾›çµ¦ï¼Œç›¸å±¬æ–¼é“ã€‚ è‡ªå¤§ä¸»å°‡ç›¸ä»¥ä¸‹ï¼Œçš†ç½®é…’å…¶å®¶ï¼Œç»éºä¹‹ã€‚ æ–¼æ˜¯å¤©å­åˆåˆ»ç‰å°æ›°ã€Œå¤©é“å°‡è»ã€ï¼Œä½¿ä½¿è¡£ç¾½è¡£ï¼Œå¤œç«‹ç™½èŒ…ä¸Šï¼Œäº”åˆ©å°‡è»äº¦è¡£ç¾½è¡£ï¼Œå¤œç«‹ç™½èŒ…ä¸Šå—å°ï¼Œä»¥ç¤ºä¸è‡£ä¹Ÿã€‚ è€Œä½©ã€Œå¤©é“ã€è€…ï¼Œä¸”ç‚ºå¤©å­é“å¤©ç¥ä¹Ÿã€‚ æ–¼æ˜¯äº”åˆ©å¸¸å¤œç¥ å…¶å®¶ï¼Œæ¬²ä»¥ä¸‹ç¥ã€‚ ç¥æœªè‡³è€Œç™¾é¬¼é›†çŸ£ï¼Œç„¶é —èƒ½ä½¿ä¹‹ã€‚ å…¶å¾Œè£æ²»è¡Œï¼Œæ±å…¥æµ·ï¼Œæ±‚å…¶å¸«äº‘ã€‚ å¤§è¦‹æ•¸æœˆï¼Œä½©å…­å°ï¼Œè²´éœ‡å¤©ä¸‹ï¼Œè€Œæµ·ä¸Šç‡•é½Šä¹‹é–’ï¼Œè«ä¸æ¤æ¥è€Œè‡ªè¨€æœ‰ç¦æ–¹ï¼Œèƒ½ç¥åƒŠçŸ£ã€‚
At this time the emperor was worried about the Yellow River breach, and the gold was not yet complete, so he appointed Da as General of Five Benefits. After more than a month, he obtained four seals, wearing those of General of Heaven Gentlemen, General of Earth Gentlemen, and General of Great Passage. The decree to the imperial secretary stated: "Formerly Yu dredged the nine Jiang rivers and breached the four Du channels. Recently the Yellow River has overflowed Gao Lu, and the dike labor has not ceased. I have ruled the empire for twenty-eight years; heaven, if it bequeaths me a gentleman, will greatly connect him to me. The Qian hexagram speaks of the 'flying dragon' and the 'great goose gradually ascending the plate'; my intent perhaps participates in this. I shall enfeoff General of Earth Gentlemen Da with two thousand households as the Marquis of Le Tong." He was granted a first-rank residence befitting a marquis, along with a thousand servants. He was given carriages, chariots, horses, canopies, curtains, and implements to fill his household. He was also married to the eldest princess of Wei, granted ten thousand jin of gold, and his settlement was moreover named Dangli Princess. The emperor personally visited the residence of Five Benefits. Imperial envoys continuously inquired after him and provided supplies along the road. From the great princess and generals and ministers below, all hosted wine feasts in his home and presented him with gifts. Then the emperor also carved a jade seal calling him "General of the Heavenly Dao," had the envoy wear feather garments and stand on white thatch at night; the General of Five Benefits also wore feather garments and stood on white thatch at night to receive the seal, to show he was not a subject. And one who wears the "Heavenly Dao" moreover guides heavenly spirits for the emperor. Then Five Benefits constantly performed night sacrifices in his home, wishing to summon spirits. The spirits had not yet arrived but a hundred ghosts had gathered; yet he was quite able to command them. After that he prepared and set out on a journey, going east into the sea to seek his teacher, they say. Da had appeared for several months, wore six seals, his nobility shook the empire, and between the seacoast regions of Yan and Qi, everyone clutched their sleeves and claimed to have forbidden methods and the ability to become divine immortals.

å…¶å¤å…­æœˆä¸­ï¼Œæ±¾é™°å·«éŒ¦ç‚ºæ°‘ç¥ é­è„½ååœŸç‡Ÿæ—ï¼Œè¦‹åœ°å¦‚é‰¤ç‹€ï¼ŒæŠè¦–å¾—é¼ã€‚ é¼å¤§ç•°æ–¼çœ¾é¼ï¼Œæ–‡é¤ç„¡æ¬¾è­˜ï¼Œæ€ªä¹‹ï¼Œè¨€åã€‚ åå‘Šæ²³æ±å¤ªå®ˆå‹ï¼Œå‹ä»¥èã€‚ å¤©å­ä½¿ä½¿é©—å•å·«å¾—é¼ç„¡å§¦è©ï¼Œä¹ƒä»¥ç¦®ç¥ ï¼Œè¿é¼è‡³ç”˜æ³‰ï¼Œå¾è¡Œï¼Œä¸Šè–¦ä¹‹ã€‚ è‡³ä¸­å±±ï¼Œæ›£æº«ï¼Œæœ‰é»ƒäº‘è“‹ç„‰ã€‚ æœ‰éºƒéï¼Œä¸Šè‡ªå°„ä¹‹ï¼Œå› ä»¥ç¥­äº‘ã€‚ è‡³é•·å®‰ï¼Œå…¬å¿å¤§å¤«çš†è­°è«‹å°Šå¯¶é¼ã€‚ å¤©å­æ›°ï¼šã€Œé–’è€…æ²³æº¢ï¼Œæ­²æ•¸ä¸ç™»ï¼Œæ•…å·¡ç¥­ååœŸï¼Œç¥ˆç‚ºç™¾å§“è‚²ç©€ã€‚ ä»Šæ­²è±å»¡æœªå ±ï¼Œé¼æ›·ç‚ºå‡ºå“‰ï¼Ÿã€ æœ‰å¸çš†æ›°ï¼šã€Œèæ˜”æ³°å¸èˆˆç¥é¼ä¸€ï¼Œä¸€è€…å£¹çµ±ï¼Œå¤©åœ°è¬ç‰©æ‰€ç³»çµ‚ä¹Ÿã€‚ é»ƒå¸ä½œå¯¶é¼ä¸‰ï¼Œè±¡å¤©åœ°äººã€‚ ç¦¹æ”¶ä¹ç‰§ä¹‹é‡‘ï¼Œé‘„ä¹é¼ã€‚ çš†å˜—äº¨é¬ºä¸Šå¸é¬¼ç¥ã€‚ é­è–å‰‡èˆˆï¼Œé¼é·äºå¤å•†ã€‚ å‘¨å¾·è¡°ï¼Œå®‹ä¹‹ç¤¾äº¡ï¼Œé¼ä¹ƒæ·ªæ²’ï¼Œä¼è€Œä¸è¦‹ã€‚ é Œäº‘ã€è‡ªå ‚å¾‚åŸºï¼Œè‡ªç¾Šå¾‚ç‰›ï¼› é¼é¼åŠé¼’ï¼Œä¸å³ä¸é©ï¼Œèƒ¡è€ƒä¹‹ä¼‘ã€ã€‚ ä»Šé¼è‡³ç”˜æ³‰ï¼Œå…‰æ½¤é¾è®Šï¼Œæ‰¿ä¼‘ç„¡ç–†ã€‚ åˆèŒ²ä¸­å±±ï¼Œæœ‰é»ƒç™½äº‘é™è“‹ï¼Œè‹¥ç¸ç‚ºç¬¦ï¼Œè·¯å¼“ä¹˜çŸ¢ï¼Œé›†ç²å£‡ä¸‹ï¼Œå ±ç¥ å¤§äº«ã€‚ å”¯å—å‘½è€Œå¸è€…å¿ƒçŸ¥å…¶æ„è€Œåˆå¾·ç„‰ã€‚ é¼å®œè¦‹æ–¼ç¥–ç¦°ï¼Œè—æ–¼å¸å»·ï¼Œä»¥åˆæ˜æ‡‰ã€‚ã€ åˆ¶æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¯ã€‚ã€
In the middle of the sixth month of that summer, the shaman Jin from Fen Yin was sacrificing to Hou Tu at the Wei Qiu for the people beside the camp, when he saw the ground in a hook-like shape; digging and inspecting, he obtained a ding. The ding was greatly different from ordinary tripods, its patterns engraved but without inscriptions; they considered it strange and reported it to the officials. The officials told Governor Sheng of Hedong, who reported it upward. The emperor sent an envoy to verify and question the shaman about obtaining the ding, finding no deceit or fraud; then he sacrificed to it with proper rites, welcomed the ding to Ganquan, followed on the journey, and the emperor offered sacrifices to it. When they arrived at Zhongshan, it was warm and clear, with yellow clouds covering overhead. A muntjac passed by, and the emperor personally shot it, then used it for sacrifice, they say. When they arrived at Chang'an, all the ministers, dukes, and grand masters discussed and petitioned to honor the treasure ding. The emperor said: "Recently the Yellow River has overflowed, and for several years the harvests have been poor; therefore I toured and sacrificed to Hou Tu, praying that the common people might grow grain. Now that the year is abundant and rich, the debt not yet repaidâ€”why has the ding emerged?" All the officials said: "We have heard that formerly the Supreme Emperor raised one divine ding; 'one' means unification, the end to which heaven, earth, and the myriad things are all tied. The Yellow Emperor made three treasure dings, symbolizing heaven, earth, and humanity. Yu collected metal from the nine regions and cast nine dings. All of them were once used to cook and offer to the Supreme God and ghosts and spirits. When sages appeared they rose up; the dings moved to Xia and Shang. When Zhou's virtue declined and Song's altar perished, the dings then submerged and remained hidden, unseen. The ode says: 'From hall to foundation, from sheep to ox; Nai dings and zun vessels, not Wu not Jiaoâ€”how to examine its good fortune.'" Now the ding has arrived at Ganquan, radiant and moist, transforming like a dragon, receiving boundless good fortune. Meeting this at Zhongshan, yellow and white clouds descended and covered it, like a beast as an omen; bows and multiplied arrows along the road gathered and obtained below the altar, repaying with great sacrificial feasts. Only those who received the mandate and became emperors know its intent in their hearts and match its virtue. The ding should appear at the ancestral temples and be stored in the imperial court, to match the bright response." The decree stated: "Approved."

Those who entered the sea seeking Penglai said it was not far, but those who could not reach it probably did not see its vapors. The emperor then sent an assistant skilled in observing vapors to await its vapors, they say.

å…¶ç§‹ï¼Œä¸Šå¹¸é›ï¼Œä¸”éƒŠã€‚ æˆ–æ›°ã€Œäº”å¸ï¼Œå¤ªä¸€ä¹‹ä½ä¹Ÿï¼Œå®œç«‹å¤ªä¸€è€Œä¸Šè¦ªéƒŠä¹‹ã€ã€‚ ä¸Šç–‘æœªå®šã€‚ é½Šäººå…¬å­«å¿æ›°ï¼šã€Œä»Šå¹´å¾—å¯¶é¼ï¼Œå…¶å†¬è¾›å·³æœ”æ—¦å†¬è‡³ï¼Œèˆ‡é»ƒå¸æ™‚ç­‰ã€‚ã€ å¿æœ‰æœ­æ›¸æ›°ï¼šã€Œé»ƒå¸å¾—å¯¶é¼å®›æœï¼Œå•æ–¼é¬¼è‡¾å€ã€‚ é¬¼è‡¾å€å°æ›°ï¼šã€ï¼»é»ƒï¼½å¸å¾—å¯¶é¼ç¥ç­–ï¼Œæ˜¯æ­²å·±é…‰æœ”æ—¦å†¬è‡³ï¼Œå¾—å¤©ä¹‹ç´€ï¼Œçµ‚è€Œå¾©å§‹ã€‚ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯é»ƒå¸è¿æ—¥æ¨ç­–ï¼Œå¾Œç‡äºŒåæ­²å¾©æœ”æ—¦å†¬è‡³ï¼Œå‡¡äºŒåæ¨ï¼Œä¸‰ç™¾å…«åå¹´ï¼Œé»ƒå¸åƒŠç™»äºå¤©ã€‚ã€ å¿å› æ‰€å¿ æ¬²å¥ä¹‹ã€‚ æ‰€å¿ è¦–å…¶æ›¸ä¸ç¶“ï¼Œç–‘å…¶å¦„æ›¸ï¼Œè¬æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¯¶é¼äº‹å·²æ±ºçŸ£ï¼Œå°šä½•ä»¥ç‚ºï¼ã€ å¿å› å¬–äººå¥ä¹‹ã€‚ ä¸Šå¤§èªªï¼Œä¹ƒå¬å•å¿ã€‚ å°æ›°ï¼šã€Œå—æ­¤æ›¸ç”³å…¬ï¼Œç”³å…¬å·²æ­»ã€‚ã€ ä¸Šæ›°ï¼šã€Œç”³å…¬ä½•äººä¹Ÿï¼Ÿã€ å¿æ›°ï¼šã€Œç”³å…¬ï¼Œé½Šäººã€‚ èˆ‡å®‰æœŸç”Ÿé€šï¼Œå—é»ƒå¸è¨€ï¼Œç„¡æ›¸ï¼Œç¨æœ‰æ­¤é¼æ›¸ã€‚ æ›°ã€æ¼¢èˆˆå¾©ç•¶é»ƒå¸ä¹‹æ™‚ã€ã€‚ æ›°ã€æ¼¢ä¹‹è–è€…åœ¨é«˜ç¥–ä¹‹å­«ä¸”æ›¾å­«ä¹Ÿã€‚ å¯¶é¼å‡ºè€Œèˆ‡ç¥é€šï¼Œå°ç¦ªã€‚ å°ç¦ªä¸ƒåäºŒç‹ï¼Œå”¯é»ƒå¸å¾—ä¸Šæ³°å±±å°ã€ã€‚ ç”³å…¬æ›°ï¼šã€æ¼¢ä¸»äº¦ç•¶ä¸Šå°ï¼Œä¸Šå°èƒ½åƒŠç™»å¤©çŸ£ã€‚ é»ƒå¸æ™‚è¬è«¸ä¾¯ï¼Œè€Œç¥éˆä¹‹å°å±…ä¸ƒåƒã€‚ å¤©ä¸‹åå±±å…«ï¼Œè€Œä¸‰åœ¨è »å¤·ï¼Œäº”åœ¨ä¸­åœ‹ã€‚ ä¸­åœ‹è¯å±±ã€é¦–å±±ã€å¤ªå®¤ã€æ³°å±±ã€æ±èŠï¼Œæ­¤äº”å±±é»ƒå¸ä¹‹æ‰€å¸¸æ¸¸ï¼Œèˆ‡ç¥æœƒã€‚ é»ƒå¸ä¸”æˆ°ä¸”å­¸åƒŠã€‚ æ‚£ç™¾å§“éå…¶é“è€…ï¼Œä¹ƒæ–·æ–¬éé¬¼ç¥è€…ã€‚ ç™¾é¤˜æ­²ç„¶å¾Œå¾—èˆ‡ç¥é€šã€‚ é»ƒå¸éƒŠé›ä¸Šå¸ï¼Œå®¿ä¸‰æœˆã€‚ é¬¼è‡¾å€è™Ÿå¤§é´»ï¼Œæ­»è‘¬é›ï¼Œæ•…é´»å†¢æ˜¯ä¹Ÿã€‚ å…¶å¾Œé»ƒå¸æ¥è¬éˆæ˜å»·ã€‚ æ˜å»·è€…ï¼Œç”˜æ³‰ä¹Ÿã€‚ æ‰€è¬‚å¯’é–€è€…ï¼Œè°·å£ä¹Ÿã€‚ é»ƒå¸é‡‡é¦–å±±éŠ…ï¼Œé‘„é¼æ–¼èŠå±±ä¸‹ã€‚ é¼æ—¢æˆï¼Œæœ‰é¾å‚èƒ¡é«¯ä¸‹è¿é»ƒå¸ã€‚ é»ƒå¸ä¸Šé¨ï¼Œç¾¤è‡£å¾Œå®®å¾ä¸Šè€…ä¸ƒåé¤˜äººï¼Œé¾ä¹ƒä¸Šå»ã€‚ é¤˜å°è‡£ä¸å¾—ä¸Šï¼Œä¹ƒæ‚‰æŒé¾é«¯ï¼Œé¾é«¯æ‹”ï¼Œå¢®ï¼Œå¢®é»ƒå¸ä¹‹å¼“ã€‚ ç™¾å§“ä»°æœ›é»ƒå¸æ—¢ä¸Šå¤©ï¼Œä¹ƒæŠ±å…¶å¼“èˆ‡èƒ¡é«¯è™Ÿï¼Œæ•…å¾Œä¸–å› åå…¶è™•æ›°é¼æ¹–ï¼Œå…¶å¼“æ›°çƒè™Ÿã€‚ã€ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯å¤©å­æ›°ï¼šã€Œå—Ÿä¹ï¼ å¾èª å¾—å¦‚é»ƒå¸ï¼Œå¾è¦–å»å¦»å­å¦‚è„«å±£è€³ã€‚ã€ ä¹ƒæ‹œå¿ç‚ºéƒï¼Œæ±ä½¿å€™ç¥æ–¼å¤ªå®¤ã€‚
That autumn, the emperor visited Yong and was about to perform the suburban sacrifice. Some said: "The Five Emperors are Tai Yi's assistants; we should establish Tai Yi and have the emperor personally perform the suburban sacrifice to it." The emperor was doubtful and undecided. Gongsun Qing from Qi said: "This year we obtained the treasure ding; that winter on the Xin Si day, the first day of the month and winter solstice, matches the time of the Yellow Emperor." Qing had a bamboo book that said: "The Yellow Emperor obtained the treasure ding at Wan Qu and asked Gui Yu Qu about it. Gui Yu Qu replied: "The Yellow Emperor obtained the treasure ding and divine strategy; that year on the Ji You day, first day of the month and winter solstice, he obtained heaven's order, which ends and begins again." Then the Yellow Emperor welcomed the sun and calculated the strategy; later every twenty years it returned to the first day of the month and winter solstice; altogether twenty calculations, three hundred eighty years, and the Yellow Emperor ascended to heaven as an immortal." Qing wished to submit it through Suo Zhong. Suo Zhong saw that the book was not classical and suspected it was a forgery; he declined, saying: "The treasure ding matter has already been decided; what more is there to do!" Qing submitted it through a favored attendant. The emperor was greatly delighted and summoned Qing for questioning. He replied: "I received this book from Shen Gong, but Shen Gong has already died." The emperor said: "Who is Shen Gong?" Qing said: "Shen Gong was from Qi. He communicated with An Qisheng and received the words of the Yellow Emperor; there were no books, only this ding book. It said: 'When Han rises again it will be like the time of the Yellow Emperor.' It said: 'The sage of Han will be among Gaozu's grandson and great-grandson. The treasure ding will emerge and communicate with the spirits, performing feng and shan. Of the seventy-two kings who performed feng and shan, only the Yellow Emperor was able to ascend Mount Tai for the feng.'" Shen Gong said: 'The Han ruler should also ascend for the feng; ascending for the feng enables one to ascend to heaven as an immortal. In the Yellow Emperor's time there were ten thousand feudal lords, and the feng of divine spirits numbered seven thousand. There are eight famous mountains in the world, with three in the barbarian Yi regions and five in the central states. The mountains of the central statesâ€”Hua Mountain, Shou Mountain, Tai Shi, Mount Tai, Dong Laiâ€”these five mountains were where the Yellow Emperor constantly traveled and met with the spirits. The Yellow Emperor learned immortality while fighting wars. Troubled by the common people who did not follow his way, he beheaded and executed those who did not believe in ghosts and spirits. Only after more than a hundred years did he succeed in communicating with the spirits. The Yellow Emperor performed the suburban sacrifice to the Supreme God at Yong and stayed for three months. Gui Yu Qu was styled Great Hong; he died and was buried at Yong, which is why it is called the Hong Tomb. After this, the Yellow Emperor received the myriad spirits at the Bright Court. The Bright Court was Ganquan. What was called the Cold Gate was Gu Kou. The Yellow Emperor gathered copper from Shou Mountain and cast the ding at the foot of Jing Mountain. When the ding was completed, a dragon descended with its beard and whiskers hanging down to welcome the Yellow Emperor. The Yellow Emperor mounted the dragon; the ministers, concubines, and others who followed and ascended numbered over seventy people, and then the dragon ascended into the sky. The remaining minor ministers could not ascend, so they all held onto the dragon's whiskers; the whiskers were pulled out, they fell, and they dropped the Yellow Emperor's bow. The common people gazed up as the Yellow Emperor ascended to heaven, then embraced his bow and the dragon's whiskers while wailing; therefore later generations named that place Ding Lake, and his bow Wu Hao.'" Then the emperor said: "Alas! If I can truly become like the Yellow Emperor, I would regard leaving my wife and children as easily as removing shoes." Then he appointed Qing as a gentleman and sent him east to await the spirits at Tai Shi.

The emperor then performed the suburban sacrifice at Yong, arrived at Long Xi, ascended Kong Tong to the west, and visited Ganquan. He ordered the sacrifice official Kuanshu and others to prepare the Tai Yi sacrifice altar, modeled after Bo Ji's Tai Yi altar, with the altar having three levels. The Five Emperors' altars encircled below it, each in their proper direction, with the Yellow Emperor's to the southwest, and eight paths for ghosts were opened. For Tai Yi, the implements used were like those for Yong's single zhi altar, but with additions of sweet wine, dates, dried meats, and the like; one badger ox was killed to serve as the sacrificial vessels and livestock offerings. And only the Five Emperors received the presentation of zu vessels, dou vessels, and sweet wine. Below it, on the ground in the four directions, fermented foods were prepared for the group of spirits, their followers, and the Big Dipper, they say. After the sacrifice, all the blessed remains were burned. The ox was white in color, with the deer placed inside it, and the pig inside the deer, all covered with water. They sacrificed to the sun with an ox, and to the moon with sheep and pigs specially. The priests and butchers for Tai Yi wore purple and embroidered garments. The Five Emperors each had their proper colors: the sun red, the moon white.

åä¸€æœˆè¾›å·³æœ”æ—¦å†¬è‡³ï¼Œæ˜§çˆ½ï¼Œå¤©å­—å§‹éƒŠæ‹œå¤ªä¸€ã€‚ æœæœæ—¥ï¼Œå¤•å¤•æœˆï¼Œå‰‡æ–ï¼› è€Œè¦‹å¤ªä¸€å¦‚é›éƒŠç¦®ã€‚ å…¶è´Šé¥—æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤©å§‹ä»¥å¯¶é¼ç¥ç­–æˆçš‡å¸ï¼Œæœ”è€Œåˆæœ”ï¼Œçµ‚è€Œå¾©å§‹ï¼Œçš‡å¸æ•¬æ‹œè¦‹ç„‰ã€‚ã€ è€Œè¡£ä¸Šé»ƒã€‚ å…¶ç¥ åˆ—ç«æ»¿å£‡ï¼Œå£‡æ—äº¨ç‚Šå…·ã€‚ æœ‰å¸äº‘ã€Œç¥ ä¸Šæœ‰å…‰ç„‰ã€ã€‚ å…¬å¿è¨€ã€Œçš‡å¸å§‹éƒŠè¦‹å¤ªä¸€äº‘é™½ï¼Œæœ‰å¸å¥‰ç‘„ç‰å˜‰ç‰²è–¦é¥—ã€‚ æ˜¯å¤œæœ‰ç¾å…‰ï¼ŒåŠæ™ï¼Œé»ƒæ°£ä¸Šå±¬å¤©ã€ã€‚ å¤ªå²å…¬ã€ç¥ å®˜å¯¬èˆ’ç­‰æ›°ï¼šã€Œç¥éˆä¹‹ä¼‘ï¼Œç¥ç¦å…†ç¥¥ï¼Œå®œå› æ­¤åœ°å…‰åŸŸç«‹å¤ªç•¤å£‡ä»¥æ˜æ‡‰ã€‚ ä»¤å¤ªç¥é ˜ï¼Œç§‹åŠè‡˜é–’ç¥ ã€‚ ä¸‰æ­²å¤©å­ä¸€éƒŠè¦‹ã€‚ã€
On the Xin Si day of the eleventh month, the first day and winter solstice, as dawn was just breaking, the emperor began the suburban sacrifice and bowed to Tai Yi. In the morning they sacrificed to the sun, in the evening to the moon, then saluted; And he saw Tai Yi following the suburban rites of Yong. The assisting priest said: "Heaven has begun by granting the emperor the treasure ding and divine strategy; new moon follows new moon, end leads to beginning again, and the emperor respectfully bows and sees it." And the clothing was yellow above. For the sacrifice, fires were arranged all around the altar, and cooking implements steamed beside the altar. The officials said: "There was light above the sacrifice." The ministers and dukes said: "The emperor began the suburban sacrifice and saw Tai Yi at Yun Yang; the officials presented xuan jade and excellent livestock as offerings. That night there was beautiful light, and during the day, yellow vapors connected upward to heaven." The Grand Historian and sacrifice official Kuanshu and others said: "The spirits' good fortune brings blessed fortune and auspicious omens; we should establish a Tai zhi altar in this illuminated region to make the response clear. Have the Grand Priest oversee sacrifices between autumn and the La festival. Once every three years the emperor performs the suburban sacrifice."

å…¶ç§‹ï¼Œç‚ºä¼å—è¶Šï¼Œå‘Šç¦±å¤ªä¸€ã€‚ ä»¥ç‰¡èŠç•«å¹¡æ—¥æœˆåŒ—æ–—ç™»é¾ï¼Œä»¥è±¡å¤ªä¸€ä¸‰æ˜Ÿï¼Œç‚ºå¤ªä¸€é‹’ï¼Œå‘½æ›°ã€Œéˆæ——ã€ã€‚ ç‚ºå…µç¦±ï¼Œå‰‡å¤ªå²å¥‰ä»¥æŒ‡æ‰€ä¼åœ‹ã€‚ è€Œäº”åˆ©å°‡è»ä½¿ä¸æ•¢å…¥æµ·ï¼Œä¹‹æ³°å±±ç¥ ã€‚ ä¸Šä½¿äººéš¨é©—ï¼Œå¯¦æ¯‹æ‰€è¦‹ã€‚ äº”åˆ©å¦„è¨€è¦‹å…¶å¸«ï¼Œå…¶æ–¹ç›¡ï¼Œå¤šä¸è®ã€‚ ä¸Šä¹ƒèª…äº”åˆ©ã€‚
That autumn, in preparation for attacking Nanyue, he informed and prayed to Tai Yi. Using male Jing wood, he drew banners of the sun, moon, Big Dipper, and ascending dragon to symbolize Tai Yi's three stars, making it the spearhead of Tai Yi, calling it the "Spirit Banner." When praying for the troops, the Grand Historian held it and pointed it at the country to be attacked. And the envoy of the General of Five Benefits dared not enter the sea, so he went to sacrifice at Mount Tai. The emperor sent someone to follow and verify, but indeed nothing was seen. Five Benefits falsely claimed to have seen his teacher; his methods were exhausted, and many were not verified. The emperor then executed Five Benefits.

å…¶å†¬ï¼Œå…¬å­«å¿å€™ç¥æ²³å—ï¼Œè¨€è¦‹åƒŠäººè·¡ç·±æ°åŸä¸Šï¼Œæœ‰ç‰©å¦‚é›‰ï¼Œå¾€ä¾†åŸä¸Šã€‚ å¤©å­è¦ªå¹¸ç·±æ°åŸè¦–è·¡ã€‚ å•å¿ï¼šã€Œå¾—æ¯‹æ•ˆæ–‡æˆã€äº”åˆ©ä¹ï¼Ÿã€ å¿æ›°ï¼šã€ŒåƒŠè€…éæœ‰æ±‚äººä¸»ï¼Œäººä¸»è€…æ±‚ä¹‹ã€‚ å…¶é“éå°‘å¯¬å‡ï¼Œç¥ä¸ä¾†ã€‚ è¨€ç¥äº‹ï¼Œäº‹å¦‚è¿‚èª•ï¼Œç©ä»¥æ­²ä¹ƒå¯è‡´ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯éƒ¡åœ‹å„é™¤é“ï¼Œç¹•æ²»å®®è§€åå±±ç¥ç¥ æ‰€ï¼Œä»¥æœ›å¹¸ï¼ˆä¹Ÿï¼‰ï¼»çŸ£ï¼½ã€‚
That winter, Gongsun Qing awaited spirits in Henan and said he saw immortal footprints on Gou Shi city walls, with something like a pheasant going back and forth on the city walls. The emperor personally visited Gou Shi city to view the tracks. He asked Qing: "Could this not be imitating Wencheng and Five Benefits?" Qing said: "Immortals do not seek out rulers; rulers seek them. Their way does not allow a little leniency, so spirits do not come. Speaking of spirit mattersâ€”such matters are circuitous and absurd; one must accumulate over years before they can be brought about." Then each commandery and kingdom cleared roads and repaired palaces and pavilions at famous mountains and spirit sacrifice sites, hoping for a visit.

å…¶æ˜¥ï¼Œæ—¢æ»…å—è¶Šï¼Œä¸Šæœ‰å¬–è‡£æå»¶å¹´ä»¥å¥½éŸ³è¦‹ã€‚ ä¸Šå–„ä¹‹ï¼Œä¸‹å…¬å¿è­°ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œæ°‘é–’ç¥ å°šæœ‰é¼“èˆæ¨‚ï¼Œä»ŠéƒŠç¥€è€Œç„¡æ¨‚ï¼Œè±ˆç¨±ä¹ï¼Ÿã€ å…¬å¿æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤è€…ç¥ å¤©åœ°çš†æœ‰æ¨‚ï¼Œè€Œç¥ç¥‡å¯å¾—è€Œç¦®ã€‚ã€ æˆ–æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤ªå¸ä½¿ç´ å¥³é¼“äº”åå¼¦ç‘Ÿï¼Œæ‚²ï¼Œå¸ç¦ä¸æ­¢ï¼Œæ•…ç ´å…¶ç‘Ÿç‚ºäºŒåäº”å¼¦ã€‚ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯å¡å—è¶Šï¼Œç¦±ç¥ å¤ªä¸€ã€ååœŸï¼Œå§‹ç”¨æ¨‚èˆï¼Œç›Šå¬æ­Œå…’ï¼Œä½œäºŒåäº”å¼¦åŠç©ºä¾¯ç´ç‘Ÿè‡ªæ­¤èµ·ã€‚
That spring, having extinguished Nanyue, the emperor's favored minister Li Yan Nian appeared with beautiful music. The emperor favored him and had the ministers and dukes discuss, saying: "Even among the people's sacrifices there are drum, dance, and music; now for suburban sacrifices there is no musicâ€”how is this fitting?" The ministers and dukes said: "In ancient times, sacrifices to heaven and earth all had music, and thus the spirits could be obtained and honored." Some said: "The Supreme Emperor had Su NÃ¼ play a fifty-string se; it was sad, the emperor forbade it but could not stop, so he broke the se into twenty-five strings." Then, having blocked Nanyue, he prayed and sacrificed to Tai Yi and Hou Tu, beginning to use music and dance, moreover summoning singing boys, and the twenty-five string instrument and kong hou, qin, and se arose from this.

å…¶ä¾†å¹´å†¬ï¼Œä¸Šè­°æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤è€…å…ˆæŒ¯å…µæ¾¤æ—…ï¼Œç„¶å¾Œå°ç¦ªã€‚ã€ ä¹ƒé‚åŒ—å·¡æœ”æ–¹ï¼Œå‹’å…µåé¤˜è¬ï¼Œé‚„ç¥­é»ƒå¸å†¢æ©‹å±±ï¼Œé‡‹å…µé ˆå¦‚ã€‚ ä¸Šæ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾èé»ƒå¸ä¸æ­»ï¼Œä»Šæœ‰å†¢ï¼Œä½•ä¹Ÿï¼Ÿã€ æˆ–å°æ›°ï¼šã€Œé»ƒå¸å·²åƒŠä¸Šå¤©ï¼Œç¾¤è‡£è‘¬å…¶è¡£å† ã€‚ã€ æ—¢è‡³ç”˜æ³‰ï¼Œç‚ºä¸”ç”¨äº‹æ³°å±±ï¼Œå…ˆé¡ç¥ å¤ªä¸€ã€‚
The following winter, the emperor discussed and said: "In ancient times, they first shook the troops and moistened the army, then performed feng and shan." Then he toured north to Shuo Fang, mustered over ten thousand troops, returned and sacrificed at the Yellow Emperor's tomb at Qiao Mountain, and released the troops to wait as before. The emperor said: "I heard the Yellow Emperor was immortal; now there is a tombâ€”what is the reason?" Some replied: "The Yellow Emperor has already become an immortal and ascended to heaven; his ministers buried his clothes and hat." Having arrived at Ganquan, in preparation for conducting affairs at Mount Tai, he first assembled offerings to sacrifice to Tai Yi.
