è‡ªå¾—å¯¶é¼ï¼Œä¸Šèˆ‡å…¬å¿è«¸ç”Ÿè­°å°ç¦ªã€‚ å°ç¦ªç”¨å¸Œæ› çµ•ï¼Œè«çŸ¥å…¶å„€ç¦®ï¼Œè€Œç¾¤å„’é‡‡å°ç¦ªå°šæ›¸ã€å‘¨å®˜ã€ç‹åˆ¶ä¹‹æœ›ç¥€å°„ç‰›äº‹ã€‚ é½Šäººä¸å…¬å¹´ä¹åé¤˜ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œå°ç¦ªè€…ï¼Œåˆä¸æ­»ä¹‹åä¹Ÿã€‚ ç§¦çš‡å¸ä¸å¾—ä¸Šå°ï¼Œé™›ä¸‹å¿…æ¬²ä¸Šï¼Œç¨ä¸Šå³ç„¡é¢¨é›¨ï¼Œé‚ä¸Šå°çŸ£ã€‚ã€ ä¸Šæ–¼æ˜¯ä¹ƒä»¤è«¸å„’ç¿’å°„ç‰›ï¼Œè‰å°ç¦ªå„€ã€‚ æ•¸å¹´ï¼Œè‡³ä¸”è¡Œã€‚ å¤©å­æ—¢èå…¬å­«å¿åŠæ–¹å£«ä¹‹è¨€ï¼Œé»ƒå¸ä»¥ä¸Šå°ç¦ªï¼Œçš†è‡´æ€ªç‰©èˆ‡ç¥é€šï¼Œæ¬²æ”¾é»ƒå¸ä»¥ä¸Šæ¥ç¥åƒŠäººè“¬èŠå£«ï¼Œé«˜ä¸–æ¯”å¾·æ–¼ä¹çš‡ï¼Œè€Œé —é‡‡å„’è¡“ä»¥æ–‡ä¹‹ã€‚ ç¾¤å„’æ—¢å·²ä¸èƒ½è¾¨æ˜å°ç¦ªäº‹ï¼Œåˆç‰½æ‹˜æ–¼è©©æ›¸å¤æ–‡è€Œä¸èƒ½é¨ã€‚ ä¸Šç‚ºå°ç¦ªç¥ å™¨ç¤ºç¾¤å„’ï¼Œç¾¤å„’æˆ–æ›°ã€Œä¸èˆ‡å¤åŒã€ï¼Œå¾åƒåˆæ›°ã€Œå¤ªå¸¸è«¸ç”Ÿè¡Œç¦®ä¸å¦‚é­¯å–„ã€ï¼Œå‘¨éœ¸å±¬åœ–å°ç¦ªäº‹ï¼Œæ–¼æ˜¯ä¸Šçµ€åƒã€éœ¸ï¼Œè€Œç›¡ç½·è«¸å„’ä¸ç”¨ã€‚
Since obtaining the treasure ding, the emperor discussed feng and shan with the ministers, dukes, and scholars. Feng and shan rituals were rarely used and had been long severed; no one knew their proper ceremonies and rites, so the group of ru scholars excerpted matters concerning gazing sacrifices and shooting oxen from the Shang Shu, Zhou Guan, and Wang Zhi. Ding Gong from Qi, over ninety years old, said: "Feng and shan unites one with the name of immortality. The Qin emperor could not ascend for the feng; if Your Majesty must ascend, gradually ascend and there will be no wind or rain, then you will successfully ascend for the feng." The emperor thereupon ordered the various ru scholars to practice shooting oxen and draft the feng and shan ceremonies. Several years later, the time arrived to set out. The emperor had heard the words of Gongsun Qing and the alchemists that the Yellow Emperor and those above performed feng and shan, all bringing strange creatures and communicating with spirits; he wished to imitate the Yellow Emperor and those above in contacting spirit immortals and Penglai gentlemen, transcending the world and matching virtue with the Nine Sovereigns, while quite excerpting ru teachings to embellish it. The group of ru scholars could not clearly distinguish the feng and shan matters, and moreover were constrained by the Shi, Shu, and ancient texts and could not freely express themselves. The emperor had feng and shan sacrificial implements made and showed them to the group of ru scholars; some of the ru said "it is not the same as in ancient times," Xu Yan moreover said "the Grand Minister's scholars perform the rites not as well as those in Lu," and Zhou Ba prepared maps of feng and shan matters; thereupon the emperor demoted Yan and Ba, and completely dismissed all the ru scholars without using them.

ä¸‰æœˆï¼Œé‚æ±å¹¸ç·±æ°ï¼Œç¦®ç™»ä¸­å¶½å¤ªå®¤ã€‚ å¾å®˜åœ¨å±±ä¸‹èè‹¥æœ‰è¨€ã€Œè¬æ­²ã€äº‘ã€‚ å•ä¸Šï¼Œä¸Šä¸è¨€ï¼› å•ä¸‹ï¼Œä¸‹ä¸è¨€ã€‚ æ–¼æ˜¯ä»¥ä¸‰ç™¾æˆ¶å°å¤ªå®¤å¥‰ç¥ ï¼Œå‘½æ›°å´‡é«˜é‚‘ã€‚ æ±ä¸Šæ³°å±±ï¼Œæ³°å±±ä¹‹è‰æœ¨è‘‰æœªç”Ÿï¼Œä¹ƒä»¤äººä¸ŠçŸ³ç«‹ä¹‹æ³°å±±å·”ã€‚
In the third month, he then visited Gou Shi to the east and ritually ascended the central peak Tai Shi. The following officials at the base of the mountain heard as if there were words saying "ten thousand years," they say. He asked those above, but they did not speak; He asked those below, but they did not speak. Then he enfeoffed three hundred households to Tai Shi to maintain the sacrifices, calling it the Chonggao settlement. He ascended Mount Tai to the east; Mount Tai's grass, trees, and leaves had not yet sprouted, so he had someone carry stone and erect it on Mount Tai's peak.

ä¸Šé‚æ±å·¡æµ·ä¸Šï¼Œè¡Œç¦®ç¥ å…«ç¥ã€‚ é½Šäººä¹‹ä¸Šç–è¨€ç¥æ€ªå¥‡æ–¹è€…ä»¥è¬æ•¸ï¼Œç„¶ç„¡é©—è€…ã€‚ ä¹ƒç›Šç™¼èˆ¹ï¼Œä»¤è¨€æµ·ä¸­ç¥å±±è€…æ•¸åƒäººæ±‚è“¬èŠç¥äººã€‚ å…¬å­«å¿æŒç¯€å¸¸å…ˆè¡Œå€™åå±±ï¼Œè‡³æ±èŠï¼Œè¨€å¤œè¦‹å¤§äººï¼Œé•·æ•¸ä¸ˆï¼Œå°±ä¹‹å‰‡ä¸è¦‹ï¼Œè¦‹å…¶è·¡ç”šå¤§ï¼Œé¡ç¦½ç¸äº‘ã€‚ ç¾¤è‡£æœ‰è¨€è¦‹ä¸€è€çˆ¶ç‰½ç‹—ï¼Œè¨€ã€Œå¾æ¬²è¦‹å·¨å…¬ã€ï¼Œå·²å¿½ä¸è¦‹ã€‚ ä¸Šå³è¦‹å¤§è·¡ï¼Œæœªä¿¡ï¼ŒåŠç¾¤è‡£æœ‰è¨€è€çˆ¶ï¼Œå‰‡å¤§ä»¥ç‚ºåƒŠäººä¹Ÿã€‚ å®¿ç•™æµ·ä¸Šï¼Œäºˆæ–¹å£«å‚³è»ŠåŠé–’ä½¿æ±‚åƒŠäººä»¥åƒæ•¸ã€‚
The emperor then toured east along the seacoast, performing rites and sacrificing to the eight spirits. Those from Qi who submitted memorials speaking of divine, strange, and marvelous methods numbered in the tens of thousands, but none were verified. Then he dispatched even more ships and ordered those who spoke of divine mountains in the seaâ€”several thousand peopleâ€”to seek the divine beings of Penglai. Gongsun Qing, holding his tally, constantly went first to await at the famous mountains; arriving at Dong Lai, he said he saw at night a great person several zhang tall, but when he approached it was gone; he saw its tracks, very large, resembling those of birds and beasts, they say. Among the ministers there were those who said they saw an old man leading a dog, who said "I wish to see the great duke," then suddenly disappeared. The emperor immediately saw the great tracks but did not yet believe; when the ministers spoke of the old man, then he greatly believed it was an immortal. He stayed lingering by the seacoast, giving alchemists relay carriages and casual envoys to seek immortals, numbering in the thousands.

å››æœˆï¼Œé‚„è‡³å¥‰é«˜ã€‚ ä¸Šå¿µè«¸å„’åŠæ–¹å£«è¨€å°ç¦ªäººäººæ®Šï¼Œä¸ç¶“ï¼Œé›£æ–½è¡Œã€‚ å¤©å­è‡³æ¢çˆ¶ï¼Œç¦®ç¥ åœ°ä¸»ã€‚ ä¹™å¯ï¼Œä»¤ä¾ä¸­å„’è€…çš®å¼è–¦ç´³ï¼Œå°„ç‰›è¡Œäº‹ã€‚ å°æ³°å±±ä¸‹æ±æ–¹ï¼Œå¦‚éƒŠç¥ å¤ªä¸€ä¹‹ç¦®ã€‚ å°å»£ä¸ˆäºŒå°ºï¼Œé«˜ä¹å°ºï¼Œå…¶ä¸‹å‰‡æœ‰ç‰ç‰’æ›¸ï¼Œæ›¸ç¥•ã€‚ ç¦®ç•¢ï¼Œå¤©å­ç¨èˆ‡ä¾ä¸­å¥‰è»Šå­ä¾¯ä¸Šæ³°å±±ï¼Œäº¦æœ‰å°ã€‚ å…¶äº‹çš†ç¦ã€‚ æ˜æ—¥ï¼Œä¸‹é™°é“ã€‚ ä¸™è¾°ï¼Œç¦ªæ³°å±±ä¸‹é˜¯æ±åŒ—è‚…ç„¶å±±ï¼Œå¦‚ç¥­ååœŸç¦®ã€‚ å¤©å­çš†è¦ªæ‹œè¦‹ï¼Œè¡£ä¸Šé»ƒè€Œç›¡ç”¨æ¨‚ç„‰ã€‚ æ±Ÿæ·®é–’ä¸€èŒ…ä¸‰è„Šç‚ºç¥è—‰ã€‚ äº”è‰²åœŸç›Šé›œå°ã€‚ ç¸±é æ–¹å¥‡ç¸èœšç¦½åŠç™½é›‰è«¸ç‰©ï¼Œé —ä»¥åŠ ç¦®ã€‚ å…•ç‰›çŠ€è±¡ä¹‹å±¬ä¸ç”¨ã€‚ çš†è‡³æ³°å±±ç¥­ååœŸã€‚ å°ç¦ªç¥ ï¼› å…¶å¤œè‹¥æœ‰å…‰ï¼Œæ™æœ‰ç™½é›²èµ·å°ä¸­ã€‚
In the fourth month, he returned to Fenggao. The emperor pondered that the various ru and alchemists spoke of feng and shan each in different ways, not following the classics, making it difficult to implement. The emperor arrived at Liang Fu and ritually sacrificed to the earth lord. On the Yi Mao day, he ordered the ru scholars in attendance, wearing leather caps and silk sashes, to shoot the ox and conduct the affairs. He performed the feng below Mount Tai to the east, following the suburban sacrifice rites for Tai Yi. The feng mound was two zhang wide and nine chi high, with jade tablets inscribed below, the writings secret. When the rites were completed, the emperor alone with the chariot officer Zi Hou from the attendants ascended Mount Tai, and there was also a feng. All its affairs were forbidden [to be spoken of]. The next day, he descended by the yin path. On the Bing Chen day, he performed the shan at Su Ran Mountain northeast below Mount Tai's base, following the rites for sacrificing to Hou Tu. The emperor personally bowed and witnessed everything, wearing yellow above and using music throughout. Between the Jiang and Huai, one thatch with three ridges served as the mat for the spirits. Five-colored earth was moreover mixed into the feng mound. Strange beasts and flying birds from distant regions, as well as white pheasants and various other things, were released and quite used to add to the rites. Pi oxen, rhinoceroses, elephants, and the like were not used. All arrived at Mount Tai to sacrifice to Hou Tu. The feng and shan sacrifices; That night it was as if there was light, and during the day white clouds rose from the feng mound.

å¤©å­å¾ç¦ªé‚„ï¼Œåæ˜å ‚ï¼Œç¾¤è‡£æ›´ä¸Šå£½ã€‚ æ–¼æ˜¯åˆ¶è©”å¾¡å²ï¼šã€Œæœ•ä»¥çœ‡çœ‡ä¹‹èº«æ‰¿è‡³å°Šï¼Œå…¢å…¢ç„‰æ‡¼ä¸ä»»ã€‚ ç¶­å¾·è²è–„ï¼Œä¸æ˜äºç¦®æ¨‚ã€‚ ä¿®ç¥ å¤ªä¸€ï¼Œè‹¥æœ‰è±¡æ™¯å…‰ï¼Œå±‘å¦‚æœ‰æœ›ï¼Œéœ‡æ–¼æ€ªç‰©ï¼Œæ¬²æ­¢ä¸æ•¢ï¼Œé‚ç™»å°å¤ªå±±ï¼Œè‡³äºæ¢çˆ¶ï¼Œè€Œå¾Œç¦ªè‚…ç„¶ã€‚ è‡ªæ–°ï¼Œå˜‰èˆ‡å£«å¤§å¤«æ›´å§‹ï¼Œè³œæ°‘ç™¾æˆ¶ç‰›ä¸€é…’åçŸ³ï¼ŒåŠ å¹´å…«åå­¤å¯¡å¸ƒå¸›äºŒåŒ¹ã€‚ å¾©åšã€å¥‰é«˜ã€è›‡ä¸˜ã€æ­·åŸï¼Œç„¡å‡ºä»Šå¹´ç§Ÿç¨…ã€‚ å…¶å¤§èµ¦å¤©ä¸‹ï¼Œå¦‚ä¹™å¯èµ¦ä»¤ã€‚ è¡Œæ‰€éæ¯‹æœ‰å¾©ä½œã€‚ äº‹åœ¨äºŒå¹´å‰ï¼Œçš†å‹¿è½æ²»ã€‚ã€ åˆä¸‹è©”æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤è€…å¤©å­äº”è¼‰ä¸€å·¡ç‹©ï¼Œç”¨äº‹æ³°å±±ï¼Œè«¸ä¾¯æœ‰æœå®¿åœ°ã€‚ å…¶ä»¤è«¸ä¾¯å„æ²»é‚¸æ³°å±±ä¸‹ã€‚ã€
The emperor returned from the shan, sat in the Bright Hall, and the ministers offered him congratulations for long life. Then he issued a decree to the imperial secretary: "I, with my humble body, receive the utmost honor, and fearfully fear I am not capable. My virtue is meager and thin; I am not clear about rites and music. I practiced sacrificing to Tai Yi; as if there were images and splendid light, small hopes as if there were expectations, shocked by strange creatures; I wished to stop but dared not, so I ascended to perform the feng on Mount Tai, arrived at Liang Fu, and then performed the shan at Su Ran. I have renewed myself and am delighted to begin anew with the scholars and officials; I grant each hundred households one ox and ten shi of wine, and add two pi of cloth and silk to those aged eighty who are orphaned or widowed. I exempt Bo, Fenggao, She Qiu, and Li Cheng from paying this year's rents and taxes. There should be a great amnesty throughout the empire, like the Yi Mao amnesty edict. In the places I passed through, there should be no repeated forced labor. Matters from two years before should all not be investigated or treated." He also issued an edict: "In ancient times, the emperor once every five years made an inspection tour and conducted affairs at Mount Tai, where the feudal lords had places to lodge in the morning. I order the feudal lords each to repair their lodgings below Mount Tai."

The emperor had already performed the feng on Mount Tai with no wind or rain disasters, and the alchemists moreover said that the various spirits of Penglai seemed about to be obtainable; the emperor then joyfully hoped to encounter them and went east again to gaze at the sea, hoping to encounter Penglai. The chariot officer Zi Hou suddenly fell ill and died in one day. The emperor then departed, went along the seaside, north to Jie Shi, toured from Liaoxi, passed along the northern border to Jiu Yuan. In the fifth month, he returned to Ganquan. The officials said the treasure ding had emerged as the Yuan Ding, and this year should be the first year of the Yuanfeng era.

That autumn, a comet appeared at Dongjing. Ten days later, a comet appeared at Sanneng. Wang Shuo, who observed vapors, said: "I waited and alone saw the fill star emerge like a melon, then enter again after the time it takes to eat a meal." All the officials said: "Your Majesty has established the Han house's feng and shan; heaven repays such virtue with auspicious stars and clouds."

The following winter, he performed the suburban sacrifice to the Five Emperors at Yong. Upon returning, he performed the worship ceremony to Taiyi. The faith stars clearly appear; the emperor reverently receives the Grand Officiant's offerings.

That spring, Gongsun Qing reported seeing divine beings on Donglai Mountain, who said they wished to see the emperor. Therefore the emperor visited Gou Shi city and appointed Qing as a middle-ranking official. He then went to Donglai, stayed there for several days, saw nothing, only giant footprints. He again sent fangshi to seek divine anomalies and gather medicinal herbs by the thousands. That year there was a drought. Therefore, having gone out without clear purpose, the emperor prayed at Wanli Sha and passed by to worship Mount Tai. He returned to Huzi, personally overseeing the repair of the river breach, stayed two days, performed a submerged sacrifice, and departed. He sent two ministers to lead troops in blocking the river breach, diverting it into two channels and restoring Yu's ancient works.

At this time, having destroyed the two Yue kingdoms, the Yue people who had surrendered said: 'The Yue people worship ghosts, and their sacrifices often manifest ghosts, which are frequently effective.' In the past, the King of Dong'ou respected ghosts and lived to one hundred sixty years. Later generations became neglectful, which is why they declined.' Gongsun Qing said: 'Immortals can be seen, but your majesty always goes hastily, which is why they are not seen.' Now your majesty can build a pavilion like the one at Gou city, place dried meat and dates there; divine beings should be attracted by this.' Moreover, immortals prefer to live in towers.' Therefore the emperor ordered pavilions built in Chang'an (the Feilian Gui Pavilion) and at Ganyuquan (the Yi Yanshou Pavilion), and had Qing hold the imperial seal and prepare offerings while awaiting divine beings. He then built the Tongtian Stalk Terrace, placed sacrificial offerings below it, intending to summon immortals and divine beings. Therefore, at Ganyuquan they rebuilt the front hall and began expanding all the palace buildings. In summer, lingzhi fungus grew inside the palace hall. The emperor, because of repairing the river and building the Tongtian Terrace, saw what appeared to be light, so he issued an edict: 'Nine stalks of lingzhi have grown in the Ganyuquan palace chambers; amnesty for all under heaven, no more forced labor.'

The next year, he attacked Chaoxian. In summer, there was a drought. The next year in winter, the emperor toured Nan commandery, arrived at Jiangling and went east. He ascended and performed rites at Tianzhu Mountain in Pan, naming it the Southern Peak. Initially, when the emperor performed feng on Taishan, northeast of Taishan at the foot there was an ancient Mingtang site, but the place was dangerous and not spacious. The emperor wished to build a Mingtang beside Fenggao, but did not yet understand its regulations and design. A man from Jinan, Gong Yu, brought and presented a diagram of the Mingtang from the Yellow Emperor's time. The Mingtang diagram showed one hall with no walls on four sides, covered with thatch, with flowing water, circular palace walls forming covered walkways, with a tower above, entered from the southwest, named Kunlun; the emperor entered from it to worship and sacrifice to the Supreme God. Therefore the emperor ordered Fenggao to build a Mingtang on the Wen, like the diagram Gong Yu brought. When the fifth year came and he performed the feng, he sacrificed to Taiyi and the Five Emperors at the upper seat of the Mingtang, and had Gao Huangdi's spirit tablet placed opposite them. He sacrificed to Hou Tu in the lower chamber, with twenty great sets of livestock. The emperor entered by the Kunlun way, and began the worship of the Mingtang like the suburban ritual. When the ritual was complete, he lit the fire below the hall. And the emperor also ascended Taishan, and had his own secret sacrifice at its peak. And at the foot of Taishan they sacrificed to the Five Emperors, each according to their direction, with Huangdi combined with Chidi, and the officials attended the sacrifices. On the mountain they lit fires, and below they all responded.

Two years later, on the jiazi day of the eleventh month at dawn of the winter solstice, the calendar calculators used the original system. The emperor returned, because of the Bo Liang disaster, and received the accounts in audience at Ganyuquan. Gongsun Qing said: 'The Yellow Emperor approached the Qingling Terrace, burned for twelve days, then the Yellow Emperor built the Mingting.' Mingting is Ganyuquan.' Fangshi often said that ancient emperors and kings had capitals at Ganyuquan. Thereafter the emperor again held audiences for the feudal lords at Ganyuquan, and Ganyuquan built lodges for the feudal lords. Yong Zhi then said: 'Yue customs have fire disasters, when rebuilding houses they must make them large, using size to conquer and subdue it.' He then built the Jianzhang Palace, designed with a thousand gates and ten thousand rooms. The front hall measured higher than the Weiyang. To the east stood the Feng Tower, towering over twenty zhang. To the west lay the Tang Center, with tiger enclosures spanning dozens of li. To the north, a vast pool was dug, with Jian Terrace rising over twenty zhang, named Taiye Pool, containing Penglai, Fangzhang, Yingzhou, and Hu Liang, imitating the divine mountains, turtles, and fish in the sea. To the south were the Jade Hall, Jade Gate, and large bird structures. He then built the Shenming Terrace and Jinggan Tower, measuring fifty zhang, with carriage roads connecting them.

Five years later, he again went to Taishan to perform the feng. On the return, he passed by and sacrificed to Hengshan.

Now the sacrifices established by the emperor are Taiyi and Hou Tu; every three years he personally performs the suburban sacrifice, established the Han house feng and shan, every five years repairs the feng. The sacrifice officials of Bo Ji for Taiyi and the Three Ones, Dark Sheep, Horse Travel, and Red Star - five in total - Kuan Shu perform rites according to the seasons. All six sacrifices are led by the Grand Officiant. As for the Eight Gods and various other gods, Mingnian, Fanshan and other named sacrifices, when traveling past they sacrifice, when leaving they stop. Sacrifices established by fangshi are each managed by themselves; when the person dies, they stop; the sacrifice officials do not manage them. Other sacrifices all remain as before. The current emperor's feng and shan, twelve years later he returned, having covered all the Five Peaks and Four Rivers. And the fangshi who awaited and sacrificed to divine beings, entered the sea seeking Penglai, in the end had no verification. And Gongsun Qing who awaited divine beings still explained away the giant footprints, but had no effectiveness. The emperor increasingly grew weary of the fangshi's strange and circuitous words, yet he maintained them without cutting off, hoping to encounter the real thing. From this time on, fangshi who spoke of divine sacrifices became increasingly numerous, yet their effectiveness could be seen. The Grand Historian says: 'I followed along in touring and sacrificing to heaven and earth, the various gods, famous mountains and rivers, and performed feng and shan.' I entered the Shou Palace and attended the sacrificial conversations with the gods, thoroughly observed the intentions of fangshi and sacrifice officials, then withdrew and arranged in order those who had affairs with ghosts and spirits since ancient times, fully seeing their outward and inward aspects. Future gentlemen may examine it. As for the details of zu vessels, dou vessels, gui scepters, and bi currency, the rites of offering and responding, then the officials preserve them.
